Title: Computer Architecture a Quantitative Approach” (1st ed.)
AuthorList: David A. Patterson and John L. Hennessy . Morgan-Kaufman, 1990.
Description: A book that encouraged each of us at our undergraduate institutions to pursue graduate studies; we later both had the pleasure of working with Patterson, who greatly shaped the foundations of our research careers.

Title: Six Easy Pieces: Essentials Of Physics Explained By Its Most Brilliant Teacher
AuthorList: Richard P. Feynman. Basic Books, 1996.
Description: This book reprints the six easiest chapters of Feynman’s Lectures on Physics, from 1963. If you like Physics, it is a fantastic read.

Title: The C Programming Language”
AuthorList: Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie. PrenticeHall, April 1988
Description: The C programming reference that everyone should have, by the people who invented the language.

Title: The Structure of Scientiﬁc Revolutions
AuthorList: Thomas S. Kuhn. University of Chicago Press, 1962.
Description: A great and famous read about the fundamentals of the scientiﬁc process. Mop-up work, anomaly, crisis, and revolution. We are mostly destined to do mop-up work, alas.

Title: The xv6 Operating system
AuthorList: Russ Cox, Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich
Description: From: http://pdos.csail.mit.edu/6.828/2008/index.html. xv6 was developed as a port of the original U NIX version 6 and represents a beautiful, clean, and simple way to understand a modern operating system.

Title: Computer Systems: A Programmer’s Perspective
AuthorList: R. Bryant and D. O’Hallaron. Addison-Wesley, 2010.
Description: Another great intro to how computer systems work. Has a little bit of overlap with this book — so if you’d like, you can skip the last few chapters of that book, or simply read them to get a different perspective on some of the same material. After all, one good way to build up your own knowledge is to hear as many other perspectives as possible, and then develop your own opinion and thoughts on the matter. You know, by thinking!

Title: Introduction to Computing Systems: From Bits and Gates to C and Beyond
AuthorList: Yale N. Patt, Sanjay J. Patel. McGraw-Hill, 2003.
Description: One of our favorite intro to computing systems books. Starts at transistors and gets you all the way up to C; the early material is particularly great.

Title: Membrane: Operating System Support for Restartable File Systems
AuthorList: S. Sundararaman, S. Subramanian, A. Rajimwale, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau, M. Swift. FAST ’10, San Jose, CA, February 2010.
Description: The great thing about writing your own class notes: you can advertise your own research. But this paper is actually pretty neat — when a ﬁle system hits a bug and crashes, Membrane auto-magically restarts it, all without applications or the rest of the system being affected.

Title: One-Level Storage System
AuthorList: T. Kilburn, D.B.G. Edwards, M.J. Lanigan, F.H. Sumner.
Description: IRE Transactions on Electronic Computers, April 1962. The Atlas pioneered much of what you see in modern systems. However, this paper is not the best read. If you were to only read one, you might try the historical perspective below [L78].

Title: SDS 940 Time-Sharing System
AuthorList: Scientiﬁc Data Systems. TECHNICAL MANUAL, SDS 90 11168, August 1968.
Description: Yes, a technical manual was the best we could ﬁnd. But it is fascinating to read these old system documents, and see how much was already in place in the late 1960’s. One of the minds behind the Berkeley Time-Sharing System (which eventually became the SDS system) was Butler Lampson, who later won a Turing award for his contributions in systems.

Title: TENEX, A Paged Time Sharing System for the PDP-10
AuthorList: D. Bobrow, J. Burchﬁel, D. Murphy, R. Tomlinson. CACM, Volume 15, Number 3, March 1972.
Description: TENEX has much of the machinery found in modern operating systems; read more about it to see how much innovation was already in place in the early 1970’s.

Title: The Evolution of Operating Systems
AuthorList: P. Brinch Hansen. In ’Classic Operating Systems: From Batch Processing to Distributed Systems.’ Springer-Verlag, New York, 2000.
Description: This essay provides an intro to a wonderful collection of papers about historically signiﬁcant systems.

Title: The GNU Manifesto
AuthorList: R. Stallman. 1985. www.gnu.org/gnu/manifesto.html.
Description: A huge part of Linux’s success was no doubt the presence of an excellent compiler, gcc, and other relevant pieces of open software, thanks to the GNU effort headed by Stallman. Stallman is a visionary when it comes to open source, and this manifesto lays out his thoughts as to why.

Title: The Manchester Mark I and Atlas: A Historical Perspective
AuthorList: S. H. Lavington. Communications of the ACM, Volume 21:1, January 1978.
Description: A nice piece of history on the early development of computer systems and the pioneering efforts of the Atlas. Of course, one could go back and read the Atlas papers themselves, but this paper provides a great overview and adds some historical perspective.

Title: The Multics System: An Examination of its Structure
AuthorList: Elliott Organick. MIT Press, 1972.
Description: A great overview of Multics. So many good ideas, and yet it was an over-designed system, shooting for too much, and thus never really worked. A classic example of what Fred Brooks would call the second-system effect [B75].

Title: The Mythical Man-Month
AuthorList: F. Brooks. Addison-Wesley, 1975.
Description: A classic text on software engineering; well worth the read.

Title: The U NIX Time-Sharing System
AuthorList: Dennis M. Ritchie, Ken Thompson. CACM, Volume 17: 7, July 1974.
Description: A great summary of U NIX written as it was taking over the world of computing, by the people who wrote it.

Title: Tolerating File-System Mistakes with EnvyFS
AuthorList: L. Bairavasundaram, S. Sundararaman, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau. USENIX ’09, San Diego, CA, June 2009.
Description: A fun paper about using multiple ﬁle systems at once to tolerate a mistake in any one of them.

Title: Policy/mechanism separation in Hydra
AuthorList: R. Levin, E. Cohen, W. Corwin, F. Pollack, W. Wulf. SOSP ’75, Austin, Texas, November 1975.
Description: An early paper about how to structure operating systems in a research OS known as Hydra. While Hydra never became a mainstream OS, some of its ideas inﬂuenced OS designers.

Title: Programming Semantics for Multiprogrammed Computations
AuthorList: Jack B. Dennis, Earl C. Van Horn.
Description: Communications of the ACM, Volume 9, Number 3, March 1966 . This paper deﬁned many of the early terms and concepts around building multiprogrammed systems.

Title: Structure of the Multics Supervisor
AuthorList: V.A. Vyssotsky, F. J. Corbato, R. M. Graham. Fall Joint Computer Conference, 1965.
Description: An early paper on Multics, which described many of the basic ideas and terms that we ﬁnd in modern systems. Some of the vision behind computing as a utility are ﬁnally being realized in modern cloud systems.

Title: The Nucleus of a Multiprogramming System
AuthorList: Per Brinch Hansen. Communications of the ACM, Volume 13:4, April 1970.
Description: This paper introduces one of the ﬁrst microkernels in operating systems history, called Nucleus. The idea of smaller, more minimal systems is a theme that rears its head repeatedly in OS history; it all began with Brinch Hansen’s work described herein.

Title: The xv6 Operating System
AuthorList: Russ Cox, Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich. From: https://github.com/mit-pdos/xv6-public.
Description: The coolest real and little OS in the world. Download and play with it to learn more about the details of how operating systems actually work. We have been using an older version (2012-01-30-1-g1c41342) and hence some examples in the book may not match the latest in the source.

Title: A fork() in the road
AuthorList: Andrew Baumann, Jonathan Appavoo, Orran Krieger, Timothy Roscoe. HotOS ’19, Bertinoro, Italy.
Description: A fun paper full of fork()ing rage. Read it to get an opposing viewpoint on the U NIX process API. Presented at the always lively HotOS workshop, where systems researchers go to present extreme opinions in the hopes of pushing the community in new directions.

Title: A Multiprocessor System Design
AuthorList: Melvin E. Conway. AFIPS ’63 Fall Joint Computer Conference, New York, USA 1963.
Description: An early paper on how to design multiprocessing systems; may be the ﬁrst place the term fork() was used in the discussion of spawning new processes.

Title: Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
AuthorList: W. Richard Stevens, Stephen A. Rago. Addison-Wesley, 2005.
Description: All nuances and subtleties of using U NIX APIs are found herein. Buy this book! Read it! And most importantly, live it.

Title: Hints for Computer Systems Design
AuthorList: Butler Lampson. ACM Operating Systems Review, Volume 15:5, October 1983.
Description: Lampson’s famous hints on how to design computer systems. You should read it at some point in your life, and probably at many points in your life.

Title: Programming Semantics for Multiprogrammed Computations
AuthorList: Jack B. Dennis and Earl C. Van Horn. Communications of the ACM, Volume 9, Number 3, March 1966.
Description: A classic paper that outlines the basics of multiprogrammed computer systems. Undoubtedly had great inﬂuence on Project MAC, Multics, and eventually U NIX.

Title: They could be twins!
AuthorList: Phoebe Jackson-Edwards. The Daily Mail. March 1, 2016..
Description: This hard-hitting piece of journalism shows a bunch of weirdly similar child/parent photos and is frankly kind of mesmerizing. Go ahead, waste two minutes of your life and check it out. But don’t forget to come back here! This, in a microcosm, is the danger of surﬁng the web.

Title: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility
AuthorList: The Quote Investigator. Available: https://quoteinvestigator.com/2015/07/23/great-power.
Description: The quote investigator concludes that the earliest mention of this concept is 1793, in a collection of decrees made at the French National Convention. The speciﬁc quote: Ils doivent envisager qu’une grande responsabilit est la suite insparable d’un grand pouvoir”, which roughly translates to They must consider that great responsibility follows inseparably from great power.” Only in 1962 did the following words appear in Spider-Man: ...with great power there must also come–great responsibility!” So it looks like the French Revolution gets credit for this one, not Stan Lee. Sorry, Stan.

Title: A Time-Sharing Debugging System for a Small Computer
AuthorList: J. McCarthy, S. Boilen, E. Fredkin, J. C. R. Licklider. AFIPS ’63 (Spring), May, 1963, New York, USA. An early paper about time-sharing that refers to using a timer interrupt; the quote that discusses it:
Description: The basic task of the channel 17 clock routine is to decide whether to remove the current user from core and if so to decide which user program to swap in as he goes out.”

Title: Alto User’s Handbook
AuthorList: Xerox. Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, September 1979. Available: http://history-computer.com/Library/AltoUsersHandbook.pdf.
Description: An amazing system, way ahead of its time. Became famous because Steve Jobs visited, took notes, and built Lisa and eventually Mac.

Title: Intel 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer’s Manual
AuthorList: Volume 3A and 3B: System Programming Guide. Intel Corporation, January 2011.
Description: This is just a boring manual, but sometimes those are useful.

Title: lmbench: Portable tools for performance analysis
AuthorList: Larry McVoy and Carl Staelin. USENIX Annual Technical Conference, January 1996.
Description: A fun paper about how to measure a number of different things about your OS and its performance. Download lmbench and give it a try.

Title: Mac OS 9
AuthorList: Apple Computer, Inc.. January 2011. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ Mac OS 9 .
Description: You can probably even ﬁnd an OS 9 emulator out there if you want to; check it out, it’s a fun little Mac!

Title: Microreboot — A Technique for Cheap Recovery
AuthorList: G. Candea, S. Kawamoto, Y. Fujiki, G. Friedman, A. Fox. OSDI ’04, San Francisco, CA, December 2004.
Description: An excellent paper pointing out how far one can go with reboot in building more robust systems.

Title: One-Level Storage System
AuthorList: T. Kilburn, D.B.G. Edwards, M.J. Lanigan, F.H. Sumner. IRE Transactions on Electronic Computers, April 1962.
Description: The Atlas pioneered much of what you see in modern systems. However, this paper is not the best one to read. If you were to only read one, you might try the historical perspective below [L78].

Title: The Geometry of Innocent Flesh on the Bone: Return-into-libc without Function Calls (on the x86)
AuthorList: Hovav Shacham. CCS ’07, October 2007.
Description: One of those awesome, mind-blowing ideas that you’ll see in research from time to time. The author shows that if you can jump into code arbitrarily, you can essentially stitch together any code sequence you like (given a large code base); read the paper for the details. The technique makes it even harder to defend against malicious attacks, alas.

Title: The Manchester Mark I and Atlas: A Historical Perspective
AuthorList: S. H. Lavington. Communications of the ACM, 21:1, January 1978.
Description: A history of the early development of computers and the pioneering efforts of Atlas.

Title: The Single UNIX Speciﬁcation, Version 3
AuthorList: The Open Group, May 2010. Available: http://www.unix.org/version3/.
Description: This is hard and painful to read, so probably avoid it if you can. Like, unless someone is paying you to read it. Or, you’re just so curious you can’t help it!

Title: Why Aren’t Operating Systems Getting Faster as Fast as Hardware?
AuthorList: J. Ousterhout. USENIX Summer Conference, June 1990.
Description: A classic paper on the nature of operating system performance.

Title: Analysis of a Time-Shared Processor
AuthorList: Leonard Kleinrock. Naval Research Logistics Quarterly, 11:1, pages 59–73, March 1964.
Description: May be the ﬁrst reference to the round-robin scheduling algorithm; certainly one of the ﬁrst analyses of said approach to scheduling a time-shared system.

Title: Animal Farm
AuthorList: George Orwell. Secker and Warburg (London), 1945.
Description: A great but depressing allegorical book about power and its corruptions. Some say it is a critique of Stalin and the pre-WWII Stalin era in the U.S.S.R; we say it’s a critique of pigs.

Title: Computer Scheduling Methods and their Countermeasures
AuthorList: Edward G. Coffman and Leonard Kleinrock. AFIPS ’68 (Spring), April 1968.
Description: An excellent early introduction to and analysis of a number of basic scheduling disciplines.

Title: Machine Repair as a Priority Waiting-Line Problem
AuthorList: Thomas E. Phipps Jr., W. R. Van Voorhis. Operations Research, 4:1, pages 76–86, February 1956.
Description: Follow-on work that generalizes the SJF approach to machine repair from Cobham’s original work; also postulates the utility of an STCF approach in such an environment. Speciﬁcally, There are certain types of repair work, ... involving much dismantling and covering the ﬂoor with nuts and bolts, which certainly should not be interrupted once undertaken; in other cases it would be inadvisable to continue work on a long job if one or more short ones became available (p.81).”

Title: Priority Assignment in Waiting Line Problems
AuthorList: A. Cobham. Journal of Operations Research, 2:70, pages 70–76, 1954.
Description: The pioneering paper on using an SJF approach in scheduling the repair of machines.

Title: The Art of Computer Systems Performance Analysis: Techniques for Experimental Design, Measurement, Simulation, and Modeling
AuthorList: R. Jain. Interscience, New York, April 1991.
Description: The standard text on computer systems measurement. A great reference for your library, for sure.

Title: The Convoy Phenomenon
AuthorList: M. Blasgen, J. Gray, M. Mitoma, T. Price. ACM Operating Systems Review, 13:2, April 1979.
Description: Perhaps the ﬁrst reference to convoys, which occurs in databases as well as the OS.

Title: The effect of context switches on cache performance
AuthorList: Jeffrey C. Mogul, Anita Borg. ASPLOS, 1991.
Description: A nice study on how cache performance can be affected by context switching; less of an issue in today’s systems where processors issue billions of instructions per second but context-switches still happen in the millisecond time range.

Title: You can’t have your cake and eat it
AuthorList: Authors: Unknown.. Wikipedia (as of December 2015). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/You can’t have your cake and eat it.
Description: The best part of this page is reading all the similar idioms from other languages. In Tamil, you can’t have both the moustache and drink the soup.”

Title: An Analysis of Decay-Usage Scheduling in Multiprocessors
AuthorList: D.H.J. Epema. SIGMETRICS ’95.
Description: A nice paper on the state of the art of scheduling back in the mid 1990s, including a good overview of the basic approach behind decay-usage schedulers.

Title: An Experimental Time-Sharing System
AuthorList: F. J. Corbato, M. M. Daggett, R. C. Daley. IFIPS 1962.
Description: A bit hard to read, but the source of many of the ﬁrst ideas in multi-level feedback scheduling. Much of this later went into Multics, which one could argue was the most inﬂuential operating system of all time.

Title: Informed Prefetching and Caching
AuthorList: R.H. Patterson, G.A. Gibson, E. Ginting, D. Stodolsky, J. Zelenka. SOSP ’95, Copper Mountain, Colorado, October 1995.
Description: A fun paper about some very cool ideas in ﬁle systems, including how applications can give the OS advice about what ﬁles it is accessing and how it plans to access them.

Title: Inside Windows NT
AuthorList: Helen Custer and David A. Solomon. Microsoft Press, 1997.
Description: The NT book, if you want to learn about something other than U NIX. Of course, why would you? OK, we’re kidding; you might actually work for Microsoft some day you know.

Title: John Ousterhout’s Home Page
AuthorList: John Ousterhout. www.stanford.edu/~ouster/.
Description: The home page of the famous Professor Ousterhout. The two co-authors of this book had the pleasure of taking graduate operating systems from Ousterhout while in graduate school; indeed, this is where the two co-authors got to know each other, eventually leading to marriage, kids, and even this book. Thus, you really can blame Ousterhout for this entire mess you’re in.

Title: Multilevel Feedback Queue Scheduling in Solaris
AuthorList: Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau. Available: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/notes-solaris.pdf.
Description: A great short set of notes by one of the authors on the details of the Solaris scheduler. OK, we are probably biased in this description, but the notes are pretty darn good.

Title: Principled Schedulability Analysis for Distributed Storage Systems using Thread Architecture Models
AuthorList: Suli Yang, Jing Liu, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. OSDI ’18, San Diego, California.
Description: A recent work of our group that demonstrates the difﬁculty of scheduling I/O requests within modern distributed storage systems such as Hive/HDFS, Cassandra, MongoDB, and Riak. Without care, a single user might be able to monopolize system resources.

Title: Solaris Internals: Solaris 10 and OpenSolaris Kernel Architecture
AuthorList: Richard McDougall. Prentice-Hall, 2006.
Description: A good book about Solaris and how it works.

Title: The Design and Implementation of the 4.3BSD U NIX Operating System
AuthorList: S.J. Lefﬂer, M.K. McKusick, M.J. Karels, J.S. Quarterman. Addison-Wesley, 1989.
Description: Another OS classic, written by four of the main people behind BSD. The later versions of this book, while more up to date, don’t quite match the beauty of this one.

Title: The Design of the U NIX Operating System
AuthorList: M.J. Bach. Prentice-Hall, 1986.
Description: One of the classic old books on how a real U NIX operating system is built; a deﬁnite must-read for kernel hackers.

Title: A Fair Share Scheduler
AuthorList: J. Kay and P. Lauder. CACM, Volume 31 Issue 1, January 1988.
Description: An early reference to a fair-share scheduler.

Title: Extending Proportional-Share Scheduling to a Network of Workstations
AuthorList: Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau and David E. Culler. PDPTA’97, June 1997.
Description: A paper by one of the authors on how to extend proportional-share scheduling to work better in a clustered environment.

Title: Inside The Linux 2.6 Completely Fair Scheduler
AuthorList: M. Tim Jones. December 15, 2009. http://ostep.org/Citations/inside-cfs.pdf.
Description: A simple overview of CFS from its earlier days. CFS was created by Ingo Molnar in a short burst of creativity which led to a 100K kernel patch developed in 62 hours.

Title: Lottery and Stride Scheduling: Flexible Proportional-Share Resource Management
AuthorList: Carl A. Waldspurger. Ph.D. Thesis, MIT, 1995.
Description: The award-winning thesis of Waldspurger’s that outlines lottery and stride scheduling. If you’re thinking of writing a Ph.D. dissertation at some point, you should always have a good example around, to give you something to strive for: this is such a good one.

Title: Lottery Scheduling: Flexible Proportional-Share Resource Management
AuthorList: Carl A. Waldspurger and William E. Weihl. OSDI ’94, November 1994.
Description: The landmark paper on lottery scheduling that got the systems community re-energized about scheduling, fair sharing, and the power of simple randomized algorithms.

Title: Memory Resource Management in VMware ESX Server
AuthorList: Carl A. Waldspurger. OSDI ’02, Boston, Massachusetts.
Description: he paper to read about memory management in VMMs (a.k.a., hypervisors). In addition to being relatively easy to read, the paper contains numerous cool ideas about this new type of VMM-level memory management.

Title: Proﬁling A Warehouse-scale Computer
AuthorList: S. Kanev, P. Ranganathan, J. P. Darago, K. Hazelwood, T. Moseley, G. Wei, D. Brooks. ISCA ’15, June, 2015, Portland, Oregon.
Description: A fascinating study of where the cycles go in modern data centers, which are increasingly where most of computing happens. Almost 20% of CPU time is spent in the operating system, 5% in the scheduler alone!

Title: Symmetric binary B-Trees: Data Structure And Maintenance Algorithms
AuthorList: Rudolf Bayer. Acta Informatica, Volume 1, Number 4, December 1972.
Description: A cool balanced tree introduced before you were born (most likely). One of many balanced trees out there; study your algorithms book for more alternatives!

Title: The Battle of the Schedulers: FreeBSD ULE vs. Linux CFS
AuthorList: J. Bouron, S. Chevalley, B. Lepers, W. Zwaenepoel, R. Gouicem, J. Lawall, G. Muller, J. Sopena. USENIX ATC ’18, July 2018, Boston, Massachusetts.
Description: A recent, detailed work comparing Linux CFS and the FreeBSD schedulers. An excellent overview of each scheduler is also provided. The result of the comparison: inconclusive (in some cases CFS was better, and in others, ULE (the BSD scheduler), was. Sometimes in life there are no easy answers.

Title: Why Numbering Should Start At Zero
AuthorList: Edsger Dijkstra, August 1982. Available: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd08xx/EWD831.PDF.
Description: A short note from E. Dijkstra, one of the pioneers of computer science. We’ll be hearing much more on this guy in the section on Concurrency. In the meanwhile, enjoy this note, which includes this motivating quote:  One of my colleagues — not a computing scientist — accused a number of younger computing scientists of ’pedantry’ because they started numbering at zero.” The note explains why doing so is logical.

Title: A Primer on Memory Consistency and Cache Coherence
AuthorList: Daniel J. Sorin, Mark D. Hill, and David A. Wood. Synthesis Lectures in Computer Architecture. Morgan and Claypool Publishers, May 2011.
Description: A deﬁnitive overview of memory consistency and multiprocessor caching. Required reading for anyone who likes to know way too much about a given topic.

Title: An Analysis of Linux Scalability to Many Cores Abstract
AuthorList: Silas Boyd-Wickizer, Austin T. Clements, Yandong Mao, Aleksey Pesterev, M. Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich. OSDI ’10, Vancouver, Canada, October 2010.
Description: A terriﬁc modern paper on the difﬁculties of scaling Linux to many cores.

Title: Earliest Eligible Virtual Deadline First: A Flexible and Accurate Mechanism for Proportional Share Resource Allocation
AuthorList: Ion Stoica and Hussein Abdel-Wahab. Technical Report TR-95-22, Old Dominion University, 1996.
Description: A tech report on this cool scheduling idea, from Ion Stoica, now a professor at U.C. Berkeley and world expert in networking, distributed systems, and many other things.

Title: Evaluating the Performance of Cache-Afﬁnity Scheduling in Shared-Memory Multiprocessors
AuthorList: Josep Torrellas, Andrew Tucker, Anoop Gupta. Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing, Volume 24:2, February 1995.
Description: This is not the ﬁrst paper on the topic, but it has citations to earlier work, and is a more readable and practical paper than some of the earlier queuingbased analysis papers.

Title: Parallel Computer Architecture: A Hardware/Software Approach
AuthorList: David E. Culler, Jaswinder Pal Singh, and Anoop Gupta. Morgan Kaufmann, 1999.
Description: A treasure ﬁlled with details about parallel machines and algorithms. As Mark Hill humorously observes on the jacket, the book contains more information than most research papers.

Title: The Implementation of the Cilk-5 Multithreaded Language
AuthorList: Matteo Frigo, Charles E. Leiserson, Keith Randall. PLDI ’98, Montreal, Canada, June 1998.
Description: Cilk is a lightweight language and runtime for writing parallel programs, and an excellent example of the work-stealing paradigm.

Title: The Performance of Spin Lock Alternatives for Shared-Memory Multiprocessors
AuthorList: Thomas E. Anderson. IEEE TPDS Volume 1:1, January 1990.
Description: A classic paper on how different locking alternatives do and don’t scale. By Tom Anderson, very well known researcher in both systems and networking. And author of a very ﬁne OS textbook, we must say.

Title: Towards Transparent CPU Scheduling
AuthorList: Joseph T. Meehean. Doctoral Dissertation at University of Wisconsin—Madison, 2011.
Description: A dissertation that covers a lot of the details of how modern Linux multiprocessor scheduling works. Pretty awesome! But, as co-advisors of Joe’s, we may be a bit biased here.

Title: Using Cache Memory To Reduce Processor-Memory Trafﬁc
AuthorList: James R. Goodman. ISCA ’83, Stockholm, Sweden, June 1983.
Description: The pioneering paper on how to use bus snooping, i.e., paying attention to requests you see on the bus, to build a cache coherence protocol. Goodman’s research over many years at Wisconsin is full of cleverness, this being but one example.

Title: A Time-Sharing Debugging System for a Small Computer
AuthorList: J. McCarthy, S. Boilen, E. Fredkin, J. C. R. Licklider. AFIPS ’63 (Spring), New York, NY, May 1963.
Description: A great early example of a system that swapped program memory to the drum” when the program wasn’t running, and then back into core” memory when it was about to be run.

Title: Improving the Reliability of Commodity Operating Systems
AuthorList: M. M. Swift, B. N. Bershad, H. M. Levy. SOSP ’03.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to show how microkernel-like thinking can improve operating system reliability.

Title: Introduction and Overview of the Multics System
AuthorList: F. J. Corbato, V. A. Vyssotsky. Fall Joint Computer Conference, 1965.
Description: A great early Multics paper. Here is the great quote about time sharing: The impetus for time-sharing ﬁrst arose from professional programmers because of their constant frustration in debugging programs at batch processing installations. Thus, the original goal was to time-share computers to allow simultaneous access by several persons while giving to each of them the illusion of having the whole machine at his disposal.”

Title: Mach: A System Software kernel
AuthorList: R. Rashid, D. Julin, D. Orr, R. Sanzi, R. Baron, A. Forin, D. Golub, M. Jones. COMPCON ’89, February 1989.
Description: Although not the ﬁrst project on microkernels per se, the Mach project at CMU was well-known and inﬂuential; it still lives today deep in the bowels of Mac OS X.

Title: Man-Computer Symbiosis
AuthorList: J. C. R. Licklider. IRE Transactions on Human Factors in Electronics, HFE-1:1, March 1960.
Description: A funky paper about how computers and people are going to enter into a symbiotic age; clearly well ahead of its time but a fascinating read nonetheless.

Title: Programming Semantics for Multiprogrammed Computations
AuthorList: Jack B. Dennis, Earl C. Van Horn. Communications of the ACM, Volume 9, Number 3, March 1966.
Description: An early paper (but not the ﬁrst) on multiprogramming.

Title: Reminiscences on the History of Time Sharing
AuthorList: John McCarthy. 1983. Available: http://www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/history/timesharing/timesharing.html.
Description: A terriﬁc historical note on where the idea of time-sharing might have come fzshortm, including some doubts towards those who cite Strachey’s work [S59] as the by pioneering work in this area..

Title: The Nucleus of a Multiprogramming System
AuthorList: Per Brinch Hansen. Communications of the ACM, 13:4, April 1970.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to suggest that the OS, or kernel, should be a minimal and ﬂexible substrate for building customized operating systems; this theme is revisited throughout OS research history.

Title: Time Sharing in Large Fast Computers
AuthorList: C. Strachey. Proceedings of the International Conference on Information Processing, UNESCO, June 1959.
Description: One of the earliest references on time sharing.

Title: Time-Sharing Computer Systems
AuthorList: J. McCarthy. Management and the Computer of the Future, MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1962.
Description: Probably McCarthy’s earliest recorded paper on time sharing. In another paper [M83], he claims to have been thinking of the idea since 1957. McCarthy left the systems area and went on to become a giant in Artiﬁcial Intelligence at Stanford, including the creation of the LISP programming language. See McCarthy’s home page for more info: http://www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/

Title: Valgrind: A Framework for Heavyweight Dynamic Binary Instrumentation
AuthorList: N. Nethercote, J. Seward. PLDI 2007, San Diego, California, June 2007.
Description: Valgrind is a lifesaver of a program for those who use unsafe languages like C. Read this paper to learn about its very cool binary instrumentation techniques – it’s really quite impressive.

Title: Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
AuthorList: W. Richard Stevens, Stephen A. Rago. Addison-Wesley, 2005.
Description: We’ve said it before, we’ll say it again: read this book many times and use it as a reference whenever you are in doubt. The authors are always surprised at how each time they read something in this book, they learn something new, even after many years of C programming.

Title: Exterminator: Automatically Correcting Memory Errors with High Probability
AuthorList: G. Novark, E. D. Berger, B. G. Zorn. PLDI 2007, San Diego, California.
Description: A cool paper on ﬁnding and correcting memory errors automatically, and a great overview of many common errors in C and C++ programs. An extended version of this paper is available CACM (Volume 51, Issue 12, December 2008).

Title: Purify: Fast Detection of Memory Leaks and Access Errors
AuthorList: R. Hastings, B. Joyce. USENIX Winter ’92.
Description: The paper behind the cool Purify tool, now a commercial product.

Title: Survey on Buffer Overﬂow Attacks and Countermeasures
AuthorList: T. Werthman. Available: www.nds.rub.de/lehre/seminar/SS06/Werthmann BufferOverﬂow.pdf.
Description: A nice survey of buffer overﬂows and some of the security problems they cause. Refers to many of the famous exploits.

Title: The C Programming Language
AuthorList: Brian Kernighan, Dennis Ritchie. Prentice-Hall 1988.
Description: The C book, by the developers of C. Read it once, do some programming, then read it again, and then keep it near your desk or wherever you program.

Title: Using Valgrind to Detect Undeﬁned Value Errors with Bit-precision
AuthorList: J. Seward, N. Nethercote. USENIX ’05.
Description: How to use valgrind to ﬁnd certain types of errors.

Title: Efﬁcient Software-based Fault Isolation
AuthorList: Robert Wahbe, Steven Lucco, Thomas E. Anderson, Susan L. Graham. SOSP ’93.
Description: A terriﬁc paper about how you can use compiler support to bound memory references from a program, without hardware support. The paper sparked renewed interest in software techniques for isolation of memory references.

Title: Is there anything other than havoc that can be wreaked?
AuthorList: Waciuma Wanjohi. October 2017.
Description: Amazingly, this enterprising reader found the answer via google’s Ngram viewing tool (available at the following URL: http://books.google.com/ngrams). The answer, thanks to Mr. Wanjohi It’s only since about 1970 that ’wreak havoc’ has been more popular than ’wreak vengeance’. In the 1800s, the word wreak was almost always followed by ’his/their vengeance’.” Apparently, when you wreak, you are up to no good, but at least wreakers have some options now.

Title: On Dynamic Program Relocation
AuthorList: W.C. McGee. IBM Systems Journal, Volume 4:3, 1965, pages 184–199.
Description: This paper is a nice summary of early work on dynamic relocation, as well as some basics on static relocation.

Title: Relocating loader for MS-DOS .EXE executable ﬁles
AuthorList: Kenneth D. A. Pillay. Microprocessors & Microsystems archive, Volume 14:7 (September 1990).
Description: An example of a relocating loader for MS-DOS. Not the ﬁrst one, but just a relatively modern example of how such a system works.

Title: System Call Support
AuthorList: Mark Smotherman. May 2004. people.cs.clemson.edu/ ~mark/syscall.html.
Description: A neat history of system call support. Smotherman has also collected some early history on items like interrupts and other fun aspects of computing history. See his web pages for more details.

Title: The Protection of Information in Computer Systems
AuthorList: J. Saltzer and M. Schroeder. CACM, July 1974.
Description: From this paper: The concepts of base-and-bound register and hardware-interpreted descriptors appeared, apparently independently, between 1957 and 1959 on three projects with diverse goals. At M.I.T., McCarthy suggested the base-and-bound idea as part of the memory protection system necessary to make time-sharing feasible. IBM independently developed the base-and-bound register as a mechanism to permit reliable multiprogramming of the Stretch (7030) computer system. At Burroughs, R. Barton suggested that hardware-interpreted descriptors would provide direct support for the naming scope rules of higher level languages in the B5000 computer system.” We found this quote on Mark Smotherman’s cool history pages [S04]; see them for more information.

Title: A note on storage fragmentation and program segmentation
AuthorList: Brian Randell. Communications of the ACM, Volume 12:7, July 1969.
Description: One of the earliest papers to discuss fragmentation.

Title: Dynamic Storage Allocation Systems
AuthorList: B. Randell and C.J. Kuehner. Communications of the ACM, Volume 11:5, May 1968.
Description: A nice overview of the differences between paging and segmentation, with some historical discussion of various machines.

Title: Dynamic Storage Allocation: A Survey and Critical Review
AuthorList: Paul R. Wilson, Mark S. Johnstone, Michael Neely, David Boles.
Description: International Workshop on Memory Management, Scotland, UK, September 1995. A great survey paper on memory allocators.

Title: Fact Segmentation
AuthorList: M. N. Greenﬁeld. Proceedings of the SJCC, Volume 21, May 1962.
Description: Another early paper on segmentation; so early that it has no references to other work.

Title: Hints for Computer Systems Design
AuthorList: Butler Lampson. ACM Operating Systems Review, 15:5, October 1983.
Description: A treasure-trove of sage advice on how to build systems. Hard to read in one sitting; take it in a little at a time, like a ﬁne wine, or a reference manual.

Title: Intel 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer’s Manuals
AuthorList: Intel. 2009. Available: http://www.intel.com/products/processor/manuals.
Description: Try reading about segmentation in here (Chapter 3 in Volume 3a); it’ll hurt your head, at least a little bit.

Title: Introduction and Overview of the Multics System
AuthorList: F. J. Corbato, V. A. Vyssotsky.
Description: Fall Joint Computer Conference, 1965. One of ﬁve papers presented on Multics at the Fall Joint Computer Conference; oh to be a ﬂy on the wall in that room that day!

Title: Program Organization and Record Keeping for Dynamic Storage
AuthorList: A. W. Holt. Communications of the ACM, Volume 4:10, October 1961.
Description: An incredibly early and difﬁcult to read paper about segmentation and some of its uses.

Title: The Art of Computer Programming: Volume I
AuthorList: Donald Knuth. Addison-Wesley, 1968.
Description: Knuth is famous not only for his early books on the Art of Computer Programming but for his typesetting system TeX which is still a powerhouse typesetting tool used by professionals today, and indeed to typeset this very book. His tomes on algorithms are a great early reference to many of the algorithms that underly computing systems today.

Title: Virtual Memory Management in the VAX/VMS Operating System
AuthorList: Henry M. Levy, Peter H. Lipman. IEEE Computer, Volume 15:3, March 1982.
Description: A classic memory management system, with lots of common sense in its design. We’ll study it in more detail in a later chapter.

Title: Virtual Memory, Processes, and Sharing in Multics
AuthorList: Robert C. Daley and Jack B. Dennis. Communications of the ACM, Volume 11:5, May 1968.
Description: An early paper on how to perform dynamic linking in Multics, which was way ahead of its time. Dynamic linking ﬁnally found its way back into systems about 20 years later, as the large X-windows libraries demanded it. Some say that these large X11 libraries were MIT’s revenge for removing support for dynamic linking in early versions of U NIX!

Title: A Fast Storage Allocator
AuthorList: Kenneth C. Knowlton. Communications of the ACM, Volume 8:10, October 1965.
Description: The common reference for buddy allocation. Random strange fact: Knuth gives credit for the idea not to Knowlton but to Harry Markowitz, a Nobel-prize winning economist. Another strange fact: Knuth communicates all of his emails via a secretary; he doesn’t send email himself, rather he tells his secretary what email to send and then the secretary does the work of emailing. Last Knuth fact: he created TeX, the tool used to typeset this book. It is an amazing piece of software 4.

Title: A Scalable Concurrent malloc(3) Implementation for FreeBSD
AuthorList: Jason Evans. April, 2006. http://people.freebsd.org/~jasone/jemalloc/bsdcan2006/jemalloc.pdf.
Description: A detailed look at how to build a real modern allocator for use in multiprocessors. The "jemalloc" allocator is in widespread use today, within FreeBSD, NetBSD, Mozilla Firefox, and within Facebook.

Title: Dynamic Storage Allocation: A Survey and Critical Review
AuthorList: Paul R. Wilson, Mark S. Johnstone, Michael Neely, David Boles. International Workshop on Memory Management, Scotland, UK, September 1995.
Description: An excellent and far-reaching survey of many facets of memory allocation. Far too much detail to go into in this tiny chapter!

Title: Hoard: A Scalable Memory Allocator for Multithreaded Applications
AuthorList: Emery D. Berger, Kathryn S. McKinley, Robert D. Blumofe, Paul R. Wilson. ASPLOS-IX, November 2000.
Description: Berger and company’s excellent allocator for multiprocessor systems. Beyond just being a fun paper, also used in practice!

Title: The Slab Allocator: An Object-Caching Kernel Memory Allocator
AuthorList: Jeff Bonwick. USENIX ’94.
Description: A cool paper about how to build an allocator for an operating system kernel, and a great example of how to specialize for particular common object sizes.

Title: Understanding glibc malloc
AuthorList: Sploitfun. February, 2015. sploitfun.wordpress.com/ 2015/02/10/understanding-glibc-malloc/.
Description: A deep dive into how glibc malloc works. Amazingly detailed and a very cool read.

Title: Intel 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer’s Manuals” Intel, 2009. Available: http://www.intel.com/products/processor/manuals.
AuthorList: In particular, pay attention to Volume 3A: System Programming Guide Part 1” and Volume 3B: System Programming Guide Part 2”.

Title: One-level Storage System
AuthorList: T. Kilburn, D.B.G. Edwards, M.J. Lanigan, F.H. Sumner. IRE Trans. EC-11, 2, 1962. Reprinted in Bell and Newell, Computer Structures: Readings and Examples”. McGraw-Hill, New York, 1971.
Description: The Atlas pioneered the idea of dividing memory into ﬁxed-sized pages and in many senses was an early form of the memory-management ideas we see in modern computer systems.

Title: The Manchester Mark I and Atlas: A Historical Perspective
AuthorList: S. H. Lavington. Communications of the ACM, Volume 21:1, January 1978.
Description: This paper is a great retrospective of some of the history of the development of some important computer systems. As we sometimes forget in the US, many of these new ideas came from overseas.

Title: A Survey on the Interaction Between Caching, Translation and Protection
AuthorList: Adam Wiggins. University of New South Wales TR UNSW-CSE-TR-0321, August, 2003.
Description: An excellent survey of how TLBs interact with other parts of the CPU pipeline, namely hardware caches.

Title: Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach
AuthorList: John Hennessy and David Patterson. Morgan-Kaufmann, 2006.
Description: A great book about computer architecture. We have a particular attachment to the classic ﬁrst edition.

Title: CPU Performance Evaluation and Execution Time Prediction Using Narrow Spectrum Benchmarking
AuthorList: Rafael H. Saavedra-Barrera. EECS Department, University of California, Berkeley. Technical Report No. UCB/CSD-92-684, February 1992..
Description: A great dissertation about how to predict execution time of applications by breaking them down into constituent pieces and knowing the cost of each piece. Probably the most interesting part that comes out of this work is the tool to measure details of the cache hierarchy (described in Chapter 5). Make sure to check out the wonderful diagrams therein.

Title: Intel 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer’s Manuals
AuthorList: Intel, 2009. Available: http://www.intel.com/products/processor/manuals.
Description: In particular, pay attention to Volume 3A: System Programming Guide” Part 1 and Volume 3B: System Programming Guide Part 2”.

Title: MIPS R4000 Microprocessor User’s Manual
AuthorList: Joe Heinrich. Prentice-Hall, June 1993. Available: http://cag.csail.mit.edu/raw/ . documents/R4400 Uman book Ed2.pdf
Description: A manual, one that is surprisingly readable. Or is it?

Title: Performance from Architecture: Comparing a RISC and a CISC with Similar Hardware Organization
AuthorList: D. Bhandarkar and Douglas W. Clark. Communications of the ACM, September 1991.
Description: A great and fair comparison between RISC and CISC. The bottom line: on similar hardware, RISC was about a factor of three better in performance.

Title: RISC-I: A Reduced Instruction Set VLSI Computer
AuthorList: D.A. Patterson and C.H. Sequin. ISCA ’81, Minneapolis, May 1981.
Description: The paper that introduced the term RISC, and started the avalanche of research into simplifying computer chips for performance.

Title: Shared-access Data Processing System
AuthorList: John F. Couleur, Edward L. Glaser. Patent 3412382, November 1968.
Description: The patent that contains the idea for an associative memory to store address translations. The idea, according to Couleur, came in 1964.

Title: The architecture of the IBM System/370
AuthorList: R.P. Case, A. Padegs. Communications of the ACM. 21:1, 73-96, January 1978.
Description: Perhaps the ﬁrst paper to use the term translation lookaside buffer. The name arises from the historical name for a cache, which was a lookaside buffer as called by those developing the Atlas system at the University of Manchester; a cache of address translations thus became a translation lookaside buffer. Even though the term lookaside buffer fell out of favor, TLB seems to have stuck, for whatever reason.

Title: The Core of the Black Canyon Computer Corporation
AuthorList: John Couleur. IEEE Annals of History of Computing, 17:4, 1995.
Description: In this fascinating historical note, Couleur talks about how he invented the TLB in 1964 while working for GE, and the fortuitous collaboration that thus ensued with the Project MAC folks at MIT.

Title: The evolution of RISC technology at IBM
AuthorList: John Cocke, V. Markstein. IBM Journal of Research and Development, 44:1/2.
Description: A summary of the ideas and work behind the IBM 801, which many consider the ﬁrst true RISC microprocessor.

Title: The SPARC Architecture Manual: Version 9
AuthorList: David L. Weaver and Tom Germond. SPARC International, San Jose, California, September 2000. Available: www.sparc.org/ standards/SPARCV9.pdf.
Description: Another manual. I bet you were hoping for a more fun citation to end this chapter.

Title: Computer Systems: A Programmer’s Perspective
AuthorList: Randal E. Bryant and David R. O’Hallaron. Addison-Wesley, 2010.
Description: We have yet to ﬁnd a good ﬁrst reference to the multi-level page table. However, this great textbook by Bryant and O’Hallaron dives into the details of x86, which at least is an early system that used such structures. It’s also just a great book to have.

Title: Multics: History
AuthorList: Available: http://www.multicians.org/history.html.
Description: This amazing web site provides a huge amount of history on the Multics system, certainly one of the most inﬂuential systems in OS history. The quote from therein: Jack Dennis of MIT contributed inﬂuential architectural ideas to the beginning of Multics, especially the idea of combining paging and segmentation.” (from Section 1.2.1)

Title: Practical, Transparent Operating System Support for Superpages
AuthorList: Juan Navarro, Sitaram Iyer, Peter Druschel, Alan Cox. OSDI ’02, Boston, Massachusetts, October 2002.
Description: A nice paper showing all the details you have to get right to incorporate large pages, or superpages, into a modern OS. Not as easy as you might think, alas.

Title: Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups
AuthorList: Mars Candy Corporation. Published at stores near you.
Description: Apparently these ﬁne confections were invented in 1928 by Harry Burnett Reese, a former dairy farmer and shipping foreman for one Milton S. Hershey. At least, that is what it says on Wikipedia. If true, Hershey and Reese probably hate each other’s guts, as any two chocolate barons should.

Title: Virtual Memory Management in the VAX/VMS Operating System
AuthorList: Hank Levy, P. Lipman. IEEE Computer, Vol. 15, No. 3, March 1982.
Description: A terriﬁc paper about a real virtual memory manager in a classic operating system, VMS. So terriﬁc, in fact, that we’ll use it to review everything we’ve learned about virtual memory thus far a few chapters from now.

Title: Virtual Memory: Issues of Implementation
AuthorList: Bruce Jacob, Trevor Mudge. IEEE Computer, June 1998.
Description: An excellent survey of a number of different systems and their approach to virtualizing memory. Plenty of details on x86, PowerPC, MIPS, and other architectures.

Title: Before Memory Was Virtual
AuthorList: Peter Denning. In the Beginning: Recollections of Software Pioneers, Wiley, November 1997.
Description: An excellent historical piece by one of the pioneers of virtual memory and working sets.

Title: Idleness is not sloth
AuthorList: Richard Golding, Peter Bosch, Carl Staelin, Tim Sullivan, John Wilkes. USENIX ATC ’95, New Orleans, Louisiana.
Description: A fun and easy-to-read discussion of how idle time can be better used in systems, with lots of good examples.

Title: Take Our Word For it
AuthorList: F. Corbato, R. Steinberg. www.takeourword.com/TOW146 (Page 4).
Description: Richard Steinberg writes: Someone has asked me the origin of the word daemon as it applies to computing. Best I can tell based on my research, the word was ﬁrst used by people on your team at Project MAC using the IBM 7094 in 1963.” Professor Corbato replies: Our use of the word daemon was inspired by the Maxwell’s daemon of physics and thermodynamics (my background is in physics). Maxwell’s daemon was an imaginary agent which helped sort molecules of different speeds and worked tirelessly in the background. We fancifully began to use the word daemon to describe background processes which worked tirelessly to perform system chores.”

Title: Virtual Memory Management in the VAX/VMS Operating System
AuthorList: Hank Levy, P. Lipman. IEEE Computer, Vol. 15, No. 3, March 1982.
Description: Not the ﬁrst place where page clustering was used, but a clear and simple explanation of how such a mechanism works. We sure cite this paper a lot!

Title: A Paging Experiment with the Multics System
AuthorList: F.J. Corbato. Included in a Festschrift published in honor of Prof. P.M. Morse. MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1969.
Description: The original (and hard to ﬁnd!) reference to the clock algorithm, though not the ﬁrst usage of a use bit. Thanks to H. Balakrishnan of MIT for digging up this paper for us.

Title: A Study of Replacement Algorithms for Virtual-Storage Computer
AuthorList: Laszlo A. Belady. IBM Systems Journal 5(2): 78-101, 1966.
Description: The paper that introduces the simple way to compute the optimal behavior of a policy (the MIN algorithm).

Title: An Anomaly in Space-time Characteristics of Certain Programs Running in a Paging Machine
AuthorList: L. A. Belady, R. A. Nelson, G. S. Shedler. Communications of the ACM, 12:6, June 1969.
Description: Introduction of the little sequence of memory references known as Belady’s Anomaly. How do Nelson and Shedler feel about this name, we wonder?

Title: An Evaluation of Buffer Management Strategies for Relational Database Systems
AuthorList: Hong-Tai Chou, David J. DeWitt. VLDB ’85, Stockholm, Sweden, August 1985.
Description: A famous database paper on the different buffering strategies you should use under a number of common database access patterns. The more general lesson: if you know something about a workload, you can tailor policies to do better than the general-purpose ones usually found in the OS.

Title: ARC: A Self-Tuning, Low Overhead Replacement Cache
AuthorList: Nimrod Megiddo and Dharmendra S. Modha. FAST 2003, February 2003, San Jose, California.
Description: An excellent modern paper about replacement algorithms, which includes a new policy, ARC, that is now used in some systems. Recognized in 2014 as a "Test of Time" award winner by the storage systems community at the FAST ’14 conference.

Title: Aspects of Cache Memory and Instruction Buffer Performance
AuthorList: Mark D. Hill. Ph.D. Dissertation, U.C. Berkeley, 1987.
Description: Mark Hill, in his dissertation work, introduced the Three C’s, which later gained wide popularity with its inclusion in H&P [HP06]. The quote from therein: I have found it useful to partition misses ... into three components intuitively based on the cause of the misses (page 49).”

Title: Cold-start vs. Warm-start Miss Ratios
AuthorList: Malcolm C. Easton, Ronald Fagin. Communications of the ACM, 21:10, October 1978.
Description: A good discussion of cold- vs. warm-start misses.

Title: Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach
AuthorList: John Hennessy and David Patterson. Morgan-Kaufmann, 2006. A marvelous book about computer architecture. Read it!

Title: Electrochemically Induced Nuclear Fusion of Deuterium
AuthorList: Martin Fleischmann, Stanley Pons. Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Volume 26, Number 2, Part 1, April, 1989.
Description: The famous paper that would have revolutionized the world in providing an easy way to generate nearly-inﬁnite power from jars of water with a little metal in them. Unfortunately, the results published (and widely publicized) by Pons and Fleischmann were impossible to reproduce, and thus these two well-meaning scientists were discredited (and certainly, mocked). The only guy really happy about this result was Marvin Hawkins, whose name was left off this paper even though he participated in the work, thus avoiding association with one of the biggest scientiﬁc goofs of the 20th century.

Title: Evaluation Techniques for Storage Hierarchies
AuthorList: R. L. Mattson, J. Gecsei, D. R. Slutz, I. L. Traiger. IBM Systems Journal, Volume 9:2, 1970.
Description: A paper that is mostly about how to simulate cache hierarchies efﬁciently; certainly a classic in that regard, as well for its excellent discussion of some of the properties of various replacement algorithms. Can you ﬁgure out why the stack property might be useful for simulating a lot of different-sized caches at once?

Title: One-level Storage System
AuthorList: T. Kilburn, D.B.G. Edwards, M.J. Lanigan, F.H. Sumner. IRE Trans. EC-11:2, 1962.
Description: Although Atlas had a use bit, it only had a very small number of pages, and thus the scanning of the use bits in large memories was not a problem the authors solved.

Title: Run-Time Adaptation in River
AuthorList: Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. ACM TOCS, 21:1, February 2003.
Description: A summary of one of the authors’ dissertation work on a system named River, where he learned that comparison against the ideal is an important technique for system designers.

Title: Virtual Memory
AuthorList: Peter J. Denning. Computing Surveys, Vol. 2, No. 3, September 1970.
Description: Denning’s early and famous survey on virtual memory systems.

Title: 2Q: A Low Overhead High Performance Buffer Management Replacement Algorithm
AuthorList: T. Johnson, D. Shasha. VLDB ’94, Santiago, Chile.
Description: A simple but effective approach to building page replacement.

Title: Cloud Atlas
AuthorList: D. Mitchell. Random House, 2004.
Description: It’s hard to pick a favorite book. There are too many! Each is great in its own unique way. But it’d be hard for these authors not to pick Cloud Atlas”, a fantastic, sprawling epic about the human condition, from where the the last quote of this chapter is lifted. If you are smart – and we think you are – you should stop reading obscure commentary in the references and instead read Cloud Atlas”; you’ll thank us later.

Title: Converting a Swap-Based System to do Paging in an Architecture Lacking Page-Reference Bits
AuthorList: O. Babaoglu, W. N. Joy. SOSP ’81, Paciﬁc Grove, California, December 1981.
Description: How to exploit existing protection machinery to emulate reference bits, from a group at Berkeley working on their own version of UNIX: the Berkeley Systems Distribution (BSD). The group was inﬂuential in the development of virtual memory, ﬁle systems, and networking.

Title: Efﬁcient Virtual Memory for Big Memory Servers
AuthorList: A. Basu, J. Gandhi, J. Chang, M. D. Hill, M. M. Swift. ISCA ’13, June 2013, Tel-Aviv, Israel.
Description: A recent work showing that TLBs matter, consuming 10% of cycles for large-memory workloads. The solution: one massive segment to hold large data sets. We go backward, so that we can go forward!

Title: Inside Windows NT
AuthorList: H. Custer, D. Solomon. Microsoft Press, 1993.
Description: The book about Windows NT that explains the system top to bottom, in more detail than you might like. But seriously, a pretty good book.

Title: KASLR is Dead: Long Live KASLR
AuthorList: D. Gruss, M. Lipp, M. Schwarz, R. Fellner, C. Maurice, S. Mangard. Engineering Secure Software and Systems, 2017. Available: https://gruss.cc/files/kaiser.pdf
Description: Excellent info on KASLR, KPTI, and beyond.

Title: On the Effectiveness of Address-space Randomization
AuthorList: H. Shacham, M. Page, B. Pfaff, E. J. Goh, N. Modadugu, D. Boneh. CCS ’04, October 2004.
Description: A description of the return-tolibc attack and its limits. Start reading, but be wary: the rabbit hole of systems security is deep...

Title: Segmented FIFO Page Replacement
AuthorList: R. Turner, H. Levy. SIGMETRICS ’81, Las Vegas, Nevada, September 1981.
Description: A short paper that shows for some workloads, segmented FIFO can approach the performance of LRU.

Title: TENEX, A Paged Time Sharing System for the PDP-10
AuthorList: D. G. Bobrow, J. D. Burchﬁel, D. L. Murphy, R. S. Tomlinson. CACM, Volume 15, March 1972.
Description: An early time-sharing OS where a number of good ideas came from. Copy-on-write was just one of those; also an inspiration for other aspects of modern systems, including process management, virtual memory, and ﬁle systems.

Title: The Geometry of Innocent Flesh on the Bone: Return-into-libc without Function Calls (on the x86)
AuthorList: H. Shacham. CCS ’07, October 2007.
Description: A generalization of return-to-libc. Dr. Beth Garner said in Basic Instinct, She’s crazy! She’s brilliant!” We might say the same about ROP.

Title: The Innovator’s Dilemma
AuthorList: Clayton M. Christenson. Harper Paperbacks, January 2003.
Description: A fantastic book about the disk-drive industry and how new innovations disrupt existing ones. A good read for business majors and computer scientists alike. Provides insight on how large and successful companies completely fail.

Title: Understanding the Linux Kernel
AuthorList: D. P. Bovet, M. Cesati. O’Reilly Media, November 2005.
Description: One of the many books you can ﬁnd on Linux, which are out of date, but still worthwhile.

Title: Understanding the Linux Virtual Memory Manager
AuthorList: M. Gorman. Prentice Hall, 2004.
Description: An in-depth look at Linux VM, but alas a little out of date.

Title: Virtual Memory and Linux
AuthorList: A. Ott. Embedded Linux Conference, April 2016. https://events.static.linuxfound.org/sites/events/ﬁles/slides/elc 2016 mem.pdf .
Description: A useful set of slides which gives an overview of the Linux VM.

Title: Virtual Memory Management in the VAX/VMS Operating System
AuthorList: H. Levy, P. Lipman. IEEE Computer, Volume 15:3, March 1982.
Description: Read the original source of most of this material. Particularly important if you wish to go to graduate school, where all you do is read papers, work, read some more papers, work more, eventually write a paper, and then work some more.

Title: Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
AuthorList: W. Richard Stevens and Stephen A. Rago. Addison-Wesley, 2005.
Description: As we’ve said many times, buy this book, and read it, in little chunks, preferably before going to bed. This way, you will actually fall asleep more quickly; more importantly, you learn a little more about how to become a serious U NIX programmer.

Title: Atomic Transactions
AuthorList: Nancy Lynch, Michael Merritt, William Weihl, Alan Fekete. Morgan Kaufmann, August 1993.
Description: A nice text on some of the theory and practice of atomic transactions for distributed systems. Perhaps a bit formal for some, but lots of good material is found herein.

Title: Cooperating sequential processes
AuthorList: Edsger W. Dijkstra. 1968. Available at this site: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd01xx/EWD123.PDF.
Description: Dijkstra has an amazing number of his old papers, notes, and thoughts recorded (for posterity) on this website at the last place he worked, the University of Texas. Much of his foundational work, however, was done years earlier while he was at the Technische Hochshule of Eindhoven (THE), including this famous paper on "cooperating sequential processes”, which basically outlines all of the thinking that has to go into writing multi-threaded programs. Dijkstra discovered much of this while working on an operating system named after his school: the "THE" operating system (said "T", "H", "E", and not like the word "the”).

Title: Solution of a problem in concurrent programming control
AuthorList: E. W. Dijkstra. Communications of the ACM, 8(9):569, September 1965.
Description: Pointed to as the ﬁrst paper of Dijkstra’s where he outlines the mutual exclusion problem and a solution. The solution, however, is not widely used; advanced hardware and OS support is needed, as we will see in the coming chapters.

Title: Transaction Processing: Concepts and Techniques
AuthorList: Jim Gray and Andreas Reuter. Morgan Kaufmann, September 1992.
Description: This book is the bible of transaction processing, written by one of the legends of the ﬁeld, Jim Gray. It is, for this reason, also considered Jim Gray’s brain dump”, in which he wrote down everything he knows about how database management systems work. Sadly, Gray passed away tragically a few years back, and many of us lost a friend and great mentor, including the co-authors of said book, who were lucky enough to interact with Gray during their graduate school years.

Title: What Are Race Conditions? Some Issues and Formalizations
AuthorList: Robert H. B. Netzer and Barton P. Miller. ACM Letters on Programming Languages and Systems, Volume 1:1, March 1992.
Description: An excellent discussion of the different types of races found in concurrent programs. In this chapter (and the next few), we focus on data races, but later we will broaden to discuss general races as well.

Title: Ad Hoc Synchronization Considered Harmful
AuthorList: Weiwei Xiong, Soyeon Park, Jiaqi Zhang, Yuanyuan Zhou, Zhiqiang Ma. OSDI 2010, Vancouver, Canada.
Description: This paper shows how seemingly simple synchronization code can lead to a surprising number of bugs. Use condition variables and do the signaling correctly!

Title: An Introduction to Programming with Threads
AuthorList: Andrew D. Birrell. DEC Technical Report, January, 1989. Available: https://birrell.org/andrew/papers/035-Threads.pdf
Description: A classic but older introduction to threaded programming. Still a worthwhile read, and freely available.

Title: Programming with POSIX Threads
AuthorList: David R. Butenhof. Addison-Wesley, May 1997.
Description: Another one of these books on threads.

Title: Programming With Threads
AuthorList: Steve Kleiman, Devang Shah, Bart Smaalders. Prentice Hall, January 1996.
Description: Probably one of the better books in this space. Get it at your local library. Or steal it from your mother. More seriously, just ask your mother for it – she’ll let you borrow it, don’t worry.

Title: PThreads Programming: by A POSIX Standard for Better Multiprocessing.
AuthorList: Dick Buttlar, Jacqueline Farrell, Bradford Nichols. O’Reilly, September 1996
Description: A reasonable book from the excellent, practical publishing house O’Reilly. Our bookshelves certainly contain a great deal of books from this company, including some excellent offerings on Perl, Python, and Javascript (particularly Crockford’s Javascript: The Good Parts”.)

Title: Algorithms for Scalable Synchronization on Shared-Memory Multiprocessors
AuthorList: John M. Mellor-Crummey and M. L. Scott. ACM TOCS, Volume 9, Issue 1, February 1991.
Description: An excellent and thorough survey on different locking algorithms. However, no operating systems support is used, just fancy hardware instructions.

Title: Cooperating sequential processes
AuthorList: Edsger W. Dijkstra. 1968. Available online here: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd01xx/EWD123.PDF.
Description: One of the early seminal papers. Discusses how Dijkstra posed the original concurrency problem, and Dekker’s solution.

Title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know about Synchronization but Were Afraid to Ask
AuthorList: Tudor David, Rachid Guerraoui, Vasileios Trigonakis. SOSP ’13, Nemacolin Woodlands Resort, Pennsylvania, November 2013.
Description: An excellent paper comparing many different ways to build locks using hardware primitives. Great to see how many ideas work on modern hardware.

Title: glibc 2.9 (include Linux pthreads implementation)
AuthorList: Many authors.. Available here: http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/glibc.
Description: In particular, take a look at the nptl subdirectory where you will ﬁnd most of the pthread support in Linux today.

Title: Guide to porting from Solaris to Linux on x86
AuthorList: Ajay Sood, April 29, 2005. Available: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-solar/.

Title: Just Win, Baby: Al Davis and His Raiders
AuthorList: Glenn Dickey. Harcourt, 1991.
Description: The book about Al Davis and his famous quote. Or, we suppose, the book is more about Al Davis and the Raiders, and not so much the quote. To be clear: we are not recommending this book, we just needed a citation.

Title: Load-Link, Store-Conditional
AuthorList: Many authors.. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LoadLink/Store-Conditional.
Description: Can you believe we referenced Wikipedia? But, we found the information there and it felt wrong not to. Further, it was useful, listing the instructions for the different architectures: ldl l/stl c and ldq l/stq c (Alpha), lwarx/stwcx (PowerPC), ll/sc (MIPS), and ldrex/strex (ARM). Actually Wikipedia is pretty amazing, so don’t be so harsh, OK?

Title: MIPS R4000 Microprocessor User’s Manual
AuthorList: Joe Heinrich. Prentice-Hall, June 1993. Available: http://cag.csail.mit.edu/raw/documents/R4400 Uman book Ed2.pdf.
Description: The old MIPS user’s manual. Download it while it still exists.

Title: Myths About the Mutual Exclusion Problem
AuthorList: G.L. Peterson. Information Processing Letters, 12(3), pages 115–116, 1981.
Description: Peterson’s algorithm introduced here.

Title: Observations on the Development of an Operating System
AuthorList: Hugh Lauer. SOSP ’81, Paciﬁc Grove, California, December 1981.
Description: A must-read retrospective about the development of the Pilot OS, an early PC operating system. Fun and full of insights.

Title: OpenSolaris Thread Library
AuthorList: Sun.. Code: src.opensolaris.org/source/xref/ onnv/onnv-gate/usr/src/lib/libc/port/threads/synch.c.
Description: Pretty interesting, although who knows what will happen now that Oracle owns Sun. Thanks to Mike Swift for the pointer.

Title: OSSpinLock Is Unsafe
AuthorList: J. McCall. mjtsai.com/blog/2015/12/16/osspinlock -is-unsafe.
Description: Calling OSSpinLock on a Mac is unsafe when using threads of different priorities – you might spin forever! So be careful, Mac fanatics, even your mighty system can be less than perfect...

Title: The Architecture of the Burroughs B5000: 20 Years Later and Still Ahead of the Times?
AuthorList: A. Mayer. 1982. Available: www.ajwm.net/amayer/papers/B5000.html.
Description: It (RDLK) is an indivisible operation which reads from and writes into a memory location.” RDLK is thus testand-set! Dave Dahm created spin locks (“Buzz Locks”) and a two-phase lock called Dahm Locks.”

Title: The SPARC Architecture Manual: Version 9
AuthorList: D. Weaver, T. Germond. SPARC International, 2000. http://www.sparc.org/standards/SPARCV9.pdf.
Description: See developers. sun.com/solaris/articles/atomic sparc/ for more on atomics.

Title: Wait-free Synchronization
AuthorList: Maurice Herlihy. ACM TOPLAS, Volume 13: 1, January 1991.
Description: A landmark paper introducing a different approach to building concurrent data structures. Because of the complexity involved, some of these ideas have been slow to gain acceptance in deployment.

Title: What Really Happened on Mars?
AuthorList: Glenn E. Reeves. research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/people/mbj/Mars Pathfinder/Authoritative Account.html.
Description: A description of priority inversion on Mars Pathﬁnder. Concurrent code correctness matters, especially in space!

Title: A Study of Linux File System Evolution
AuthorList: Lanyue Lu, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau, Shan Lu. FAST ’13, San Jose, CA, February 2013.
Description: Our paper that studies every patch to Linux ﬁle systems over nearly a decade. Lots of fun ﬁndings in there; read it to see! The work was painful to do though; the poor graduate student, Lanyue Lu, had to look through every single patch by hand in order to understand what they did.

Title: An Analysis of Linux Scalability to Many Cores
AuthorList: Silas Boyd-Wickizer, Austin T. Clements, Yandong Mao, Aleksey Pesterev, M. Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich . OSDI ’10, Vancouver, Canada, October 2010.
Description: A great study of how Linux performs on multicore machines, as well as some simple solutions. Includes a neat sloppy counter to solve one form of the scalable counting problem.

Title: Concurrent Data Structures
AuthorList: Mark Moir and Nir Shavit. In Handbook of Data Structures and Applications (Editors D. Metha and S.Sahni). Chapman and Hall/CRC Press, 2004. Available: www.cs.tau.ac.il/~shanir/concurrent-data-structures.pdf.
Description: A short but relatively comprehensive reference on concurrent data structures. Though it is missing some of the latest works in the area (due to its age), it remains an incredibly useful reference.

Title: Making the Common Case the Only Case with Anticipatory Memory Allocation
AuthorList: Swaminathan Sundararaman, Yupu Zhang, Sriram Subramanian, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau . FAST ’11, San Jose, CA, February 2011.
Description: Our work on removing possibly-failing allocation calls from kernel code paths. By allocating all potentially needed memory before doing any work, we avoid failure deep down in the storage stack.

Title: Nonblocking Algorithms and Preemption-safe Locking on by Multiprogrammed Shared-memory Multiprocessors.
AuthorList: M. Michael, M. Scott. Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing, Vol. 51, No. 1, 1998
Description: Professor Scott and his students have been at the forefront of concurrent algorithms and data structures for many years; check out his web page, numerous papers, or books to ﬁnd out more.

Title: Operating System Principles
AuthorList: Per Brinch Hansen. Prentice-Hall, 1973. Available: http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=540365.
Description: One of the ﬁrst books on operating systems; certainly ahead of its time. Introduced monitors as a concurrency primitive.

Title: Solaris Internals: Core Kernel Architecture
AuthorList: Jim Mauro and Richard McDougall. Prentice Hall, October 2000.
Description: The Solaris book. You should also read this, if you want to learn about something other than Linux.

Title: The Search For Fast, Scalable Counters
AuthorList: Jonathan Corbet. February 1, 2006. Available: https://lwn.net/Articles/170003.
Description: LWN has many wonderful articles about the latest in Linux This article is a short description of scalable approximate counting; read it, and others, to learn more about the latest in Linux.

Title: Understanding the Linux Kernel (Third Edition)
AuthorList: Daniel P. Bovet and Marco Cesati. O’Reilly Media, November 2005.
Description: The classic book on the Linux kernel. You should read it.

AuthorList: George Orwell. Secker and Warburg, 1949.
Description: A little heavy-handed, but of course a must read. That said, we kind of gave away the ending by quoting the last sentence. Sorry! And if the government is reading this, let us just say that we think that the government is "double plus good”. Hear that, our pals at the NSA?

Title: Cooperating sequential processes
AuthorList: Edsger W. Dijkstra. 1968. Available online here: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd01xx/EWD123.PDF.
Description: Another classic from Dijkstra; reading his early works on concurrency will teach you much of what you need to know.

Title: Experience with Processes and Monitors in Mesa
AuthorList: B.W. Lampson, D.R. Redell. Communications of the ACM. 23:2, pages 105-117, February 1980.
Description: A terriﬁc paper about how to actually implement signaling and condition variables in a real system, leading to the term "Mesa" semantics for what it mzshortns to be woken up; the older semantics, developed by Tony Hoare [H74], then became known as "Hoare" semantics, which is hard to say out loud in class with a straight face.

Title: Information Streams Sharing a Finite Buffer
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. Information Processing Letters 1: 179180, 1972. Available: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd03xx/EWD329.PDF
Description: The famous paper that introduced the producer/consumer problem.

Title: Monitors: An Operating System Structuring Concept
AuthorList: C.A.R. Hoare. Communications of the ACM, 17:10, pages 549–557, October 1974.
Description: Hoare did a fair amount of theoretical work in concurrency. However, he is still probably most known for his work on Quicksort, the coolest sorting algorithm in the world, at least according to these authors.

Title: My recollections of operating system design
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. April, 2001. Available: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd13xx/EWD1303.PDF.
Description: A fascinating read for those of you interested in how the pioneers of our ﬁeld came up with some very basic and fundamental concepts, including ideas like "interrupts" and even a stack”!

Title: Pthread cond signal Man Page
AuthorList: Mysterious author. March, 2011. Available online: http://linux.die.net/man/3/pthread cond signal.
Description: The Linux man page shows a nice simple example of why a thread might get a spurious wakeup, due to race conditions within the signal/wakeup code.

Title: A Note on Two Problems in Connexion with Graphs
AuthorList: E. W. Dijkstra. Numerische Mathematik 1, 269–271, 1959. Available: http://www-m3.ma.tum.de/twiki/pub/MN0506/ WebHome/dijkstra.pdf.
Description: Can you believe people worked on algorithms in 1959? We can’t. Even before computers were any fun to use, these people had a sense that they would transform the world...

Title: Aspects of Cache Memory and Instruction Buffer Performance
AuthorList: Mark D. Hill. Ph.D. Dissertation, U.C. Berkeley, 1987.
Description: Hill’s dissertation work, for those obsessed with caching in early systems. A great example of a quantitative dissertation.

Title: Concurrent Control with Readers and Writers
AuthorList: P.J. Courtois, F. Heymans, D.L. Parnas. Communications of the ACM, 14:10, October 1971.
Description: The introduction of the reader-writer problem, and a simple solution. Later work introduced more complex solutions, skipped here because, well, they are pretty complex.

Title: Go-to Statement Considered Harmful
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. CACM, volume 11(3), March 1968. http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd02xx/EWD215.PDF.
Description: Sometimes thought of as the beginning of the ﬁeld of software engineering.

Title: Hierarchical ordering of sequential processes
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. Available online here: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd03xx/EWD310.PDF.
Description: Presents numerous concurrency problems, including Dining Philosophers. The wikipedia page about this problem is also useful.

Title: Hints for Computer Systems Design
AuthorList: Butler Lampson. ACM Operating Systems Review, 15:5, October 1983.
Description: Lampson, a famous systems researcher, loved using hints in the design of computer systems. A hint is something that is often correct but can be wrong; in this use, a signal() is telling a waiting thread that it changed the condition that the waiter was waiting on, but not to trust that the condition will be in the desired state when the waiting thread wakes up. In this paper about hints for designing systems, one of Lampson’s general hints is that you should use hints. It is not as confusing as it sounds.

Title: Implementing Condition Variables with Semaphores
AuthorList: Andrew Birrell. December 2004.
Description: An interesting read on how difﬁcult implementing CVs on top of semaphores really is, and the mistakes the author and co-workers made along the way. Particularly relevant because the group had done a ton of concurrent programming; Birrell, for example, is known for (among other things) writing various thread-programming guides.

Title: Information Streams Sharing a Finite Buffer
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. Information Processing Letters 1, 1972. http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd03xx/EWD329.PDF.
Description: Did Dijkstra invent everything? No, but maybe close. He certainly was the ﬁrst to clearly write down what the problems were in concurrent code. However, practitioners in OS design knew of many of the problems described by Dijkstra, so perhaps giving him too much credit would be a misrepresentation.

Title: Re: NT kernel guy playing with Linux
AuthorList: Linus Torvalds. June 27, 1999. Available: https://yarchive.net/comp/linux/semaphores.html.
Description: A response from Linus himself about the utility of semaphores, including the throttling case we mention in the text. As always, Linus is slightly insulting but quite informative.

Title: Real-world Concurrency
AuthorList: Bryan Cantrill, Jeff Bonwick. ACM Queue. Volume 6, No. 5. September 2008.
Description: A nice article by some kernel hackers from a company formerly known as Sun on the real problems faced in concurrent code.

Title: The Little Book of Semaphores
AuthorList: A.B. Downey. Available at the following site: http://greenteapress.com/semaphores/.
Description: A nice (and free!) book about semaphores. Lots of fun problems to solve, if you like that sort of thing.

Title: The Structure of the THE Multiprogramming System
AuthorList: E.W. Dijkstra. CACM, volume 11(5), 1968.
Description: One of the earliest papers to point out that systems work in computer science is an engaging intellectual endeavor. Also argues strongly for modularity in the form of layered systems.

Title: Transaction Processing: Concepts and Techniques
AuthorList: Jim Gray, Andreas Reuter. Morgan Kaufmann, September 1992.
Description: The exact quote that we ﬁnd particularly humorous is found on page 485, at the top of Section 8.8: The ﬁrst multiprocessors, circa 1960, had test and set instructions ... presumably the OS implementors worked out the appropriate algorithms, although Dijkstra is generally credited with inventing semaphores many years later.” Oh, snap!

Title: A Methodology for Implementing Highly Concurrent Data Objects
AuthorList: Maurice Herlihy. ACM TOPLAS, 15:5, November 1993.
Description: A nice overview of lock-free and wait-free structures. Both approaches eschew locks, but wait-free approaches are harder to realize, as they try to ensure than any operation on a concurrent structure will terminate in a ﬁnite number of steps (e.g., no unbounded looping).

Title: A Pragmatic Implementation of Non-blocking Linked-lists
AuthorList: Tim Harris. International Conference on Distributed Computing (DISC), 2001.
Description: A relatively modern example of the difﬁculties of building something as simple as a concurrent linked list without locks.

Title: Concurrency Control and Recovery in Database Systems
AuthorList: Philip A. Bernstein, Vassos Hadzilacos, Nathan Goodman. Addison-Wesley, 1987.
