Description: The classic text on concurrency in database management systems. As you can tell, understanding concurrency, deadlock, and other topics in the world of databases is a world unto itself. Study it and ﬁnd out for yourself.

Title: Deadlock Detection in Distributed Databases
AuthorList: Edgar Knapp. ACM Computing Surveys, 19:4, December 1987.
Description: An excellent overview of deadlock detection in distributed database systems. Also points to a number of other related works, and thus is a good place to start your reading.

Title: Deadlock Immunity: Enabling Systems To Defend Against Deadlocks
AuthorList: Horatiu Jula, Daniel Tralamazza, Cristian Zamﬁr, George Candea. OSDI ’08, San Diego, CA, December 2008.
Description: An excellent recent paper on deadlocks and how to avoid getting caught in the same ones over and over again in a particular system.

Title: Een algorithme ter voorkoming van de dodelijke omarming
AuthorList: Edsger Dijkstra. 1964. Available: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd01xx/EWD108.PDF.
Description: Indeed, not only did Dijkstra come up with a number of solutions to the deadlock problem, he was the ﬁrst to note its existence, at least in written form. However, he called it the "deadly embrace”, which (thankfully) did not catch on.

Title: Learning from Mistakes — A Comprehensive Study on Real World Concurrency Bug Characteristics
AuthorList: Shan Lu, Soyeon Park, Eunsoo Seo, Yuanyuan Zhou. ASPLOS ’08, March 2008, Seattle, Washington.
Description: The ﬁrst in-depth study of concurrency bugs in real software, and the basis for this chapter. Look at Y.Y. Zhou’s or Shan Lu’s web pages for many more interesting papers on bugs.

Title: Linux File Memory Map Code
AuthorList: Linus Torvalds and many others. Available online at: http://lxr.free-electrons.com/source/mm/filemap.c.
Description: Thanks to Michael Walﬁsh (NYU) for pointing out this precious example. The real world, as you can see in this ﬁle, can be a bit more complex than the simple clarity found in textbooks...

Title: MapReduce: Simpliﬁed Data Processing on Large Clusters
AuthorList: Sanjay Ghemawhat, Jeff Dean. OSDI ’04, San Francisco, CA, October 2004.
Description: The MapReduce paper ushered in the era of large-scale data processing, and proposes a framework for performing such computations on clusters of generally unreliable machines.

Title: Soul of a New Machine
AuthorList: Tracy Kidder. Backbay Books, 2000 (reprint of 1980 ver-sion).
Description: A must-read for any systems builder or engineer, detailing the early days of how a team inside Data General (DG), led by Tom West, worked to produce a "new machine.” Kidder’s other books are also excellent, including "Mountains beyond Mountains.” Or maybe you don’t agree with us, comma?

Title: System Deadlocks
AuthorList: E.G. Coffman, M.J. Elphick, A. Shoshani. ACM Computing Surveys, 3:2, June 1971.
Description: The classic paper outlining the conditions for deadlock and how you might go about dealing with it. There are certainly some earlier papers on this topic; see the references within this paper for details.

Title: Wait-free Synchronization
AuthorList: Maurice Herlihy . ACM TOPLAS, 13:1, January 1991.
Description: Herlihy’s work pioneers the ideas behind wait-free approaches to writing concurrent programs. These approaches tend to be complex and hard, often more difﬁcult than using locks correctly, probably limiting their success in the real world.

Title: Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
AuthorList: W. Richard Stevens and Stephen A. Rago. Addison-Wesley, 2005.
Description: Once again, we refer to the classic must-have-on-your-bookshelf book of U NIX systems programming. If there is some detail you need to know, it is in here.

Title: Capriccio: Scalable Threads for Internet Services
AuthorList: Rob von Behren, Jeremy Condit, Feng Zhou, George C. Necula, Eric Brewer. SOSP ’03, Lake George, New York, October 2003.
Description: A paper about how to make threads work at extreme scale; a counter to all the event-based work ongoing at the time.

Title: Cooperative Task Management Without Manual Stack Management
AuthorList: Atul Adya, Jon Howell, Marvin Theimer, William J. Bolosky, John R. Douceur. USENIX ATC ’02, Monterey, CA, June 2002.
Description: This gem of a paper is the ﬁrst to clearly articulate some of the difﬁculties of event-based concurrency, and suggests some simple solutions, as well explores the even crazier idea of combining the two types of concurrency management into a single application!

Title: Flash: An Efﬁcient and Portable Web Server
AuthorList: Vivek S. Pai, Peter Druschel, Willy Zwaenepoel. USENIX ’99, Monterey, CA, June 1999.
Description: A pioneering paper on how to structure web servers in the then-burgeoning Internet era. Read it to understand the basics as well as to see the authors’ ideas on how to build hybrids when support for asynchronous I/O is lacking.

Title: Node.js Documentation
AuthorList: the folks who built node.js. Available: nodejs.org/api.
Description: One of the many cool new frameworks that help you readily build web services and applications. Every modern systems hacker should be proﬁcient in frameworks such as this one (and likely, more than one). Spend the time and do some development in one of these worlds and become an expert.

Title: Programming With Continuations
AuthorList: Daniel P. Friedman, Christopher T. Haynes, Eugene E. Kohlbecker. In Program Transformation and Programming Environments, Springer Verlag, 1984.
Description: The classic reference to this old idea from the world of programming languages. Now increasingly popular in some modern languages.

Title: SEDA: An Architecture for Well-Conditioned, Scalable Internet Services
AuthorList: Matt Welsh, David Culler, and Eric Brewer. SOSP ’01, Banff, Canada, October 2001.
Description: A nice twist on event-based serving that combines threads, queues, and event-based handling into one streamlined whole. Some of these ideas have found their way into the infrastructures of companies such as Google, Amazon, and elsewhere.

Title: Why Threads Are A Bad Idea (for most purposes)
AuthorList: John Ousterhout. Invited Talk at USENIX ’96, San Diego, CA, January 1996.
Description: A great talk about how threads aren’t a great match for GUI-based applications (but the ideas are more general). Ousterhout formed many of these opinions while he was developing Tcl/Tk, a cool scripting language and toolkit that made it 100x easier to develop GUI-based applications than the state of the art at the time. While the Tk GUI toolkit lives on (in Python for example), Tcl seems to be slowly dying (unfortunately).

Title: An Empirical Study of Operating System Errors
AuthorList: Andy Chou, Junfeng Yang, Benjamin Chelf, Seth Hallem, Dawson Engler. SOSP ’01.
Description: One of the ﬁrst papers to systematically explore how many bugs are in modern operating systems. Among other neat ﬁndings, the authors show that device drivers have something like seven times more bugs than mainline kernel code.

Title: AT Attachment Interface for Disk Drives
AuthorList: Lawrence J. Lamers. Reference number: ANSI X3.221, 1994. Available: ftp://ftp.t10.org/t13/project/d0791r4c-ATA-1.pdf.
Description: A rather dry document about device interfaces. Read it at your own peril.

Title: EIO: Error-handling is Occasionally Correct
AuthorList: Haryadi Gunawi, Cindy Rubio-Gonzalez, Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau, Ben Liblit. FAST ’08, San Jose, CA, February 2008.
Description: Our own work on building a tool to ﬁnd code in Linux ﬁle systems that does not handle error return properly. We found hundreds and hundreds of bugs, many of which have now been ﬁxed.

Title: Eliminating Receive Livelock in an Interrupt-driven Kernel
AuthorList: Jeffrey Mogul, K. K. Ramakrishnan. USENIX ’96, San Diego, CA, January 1996.
Description: Mogul and colleagues did a great deal of pioneering work on web server network performance. This paper is but one example.

Title: Hacker News
AuthorList: Many contributors. Available: https://news.ycombinator.com. One of the better aggregrators for tech-related stuff.
Description: Once back in 2014, this book became a highly-ranked entry, leading to 1 million chapter downloads in just one day! Sadly, we have yet to re-experience such a high.

Title: Hard Disk Driver
AuthorList: Washington State Course Homepage. Available online at this site: http://eecs.wsu.edu/~cs460/cs560/HDdriver.html.
Description: A nice summary of a simple IDE disk drive’s interface and how to build a device driver for it.

Title: Improving the Reliability of Commodity Operating Systems
AuthorList: Michael M. Swift, Brian N. Bershad, Henry M. Levy. SOSP ’03.
Description: Swift’s work revived interest in a more microkernel-like approach to operating systems; minimally, it ﬁnally gave some good reasons why address-space based protection could be useful in a modern OS.

Title: Intel Core i7-7700K review: Kaby Lake Debuts for Desktop
AuthorList: Joel Hruska. January 3, 2017. www.extremetech.com/extreme/241950-intels-core-i7-7700k-reviewed-kaby -lake-debuts-desktop.
Description: An in-depth review of a recent Intel chipset, including CPUs and the I/O subsystem.

Title: Interrupts
AuthorList: Mark Smotherman. July ’08. Available: http://people.cs.clemson.edu/ ~mark/interrupts.html.
Description: A treasure trove of information on the history of interrupts, DMA, and related early ideas in computing.

Title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces (Chapters: Crash Consistency: FSCK and Journaling and Log-Structured File Systems)
AuthorList: Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau and Andrea ArpaciDusseau. Arpaci-Dusseau Books, 2014.
Description: A description of a ﬁle-system checker and how it works, which requires low-level access to disk devices not normally provided by the ﬁle system directly.

Title: The xv6 Operating System
AuthorList: Russ Cox, Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich. From: http://pdos.csail.mit.edu/6.828/2008/index.html.
Description: See ide.c for the IDE device driver, with a few more details therein.

Title: vIC: Interrupt Coalescing for Virtual Machine Storage Device IO
AuthorList: Irfan Ahmad, Ajay Gulati, Ali Mashtizadeh. USENIX ’11.
Description: A terriﬁc survey of interrupt coalescing in traditional and virtualized environments.

Title: What Every Programmer Should Know About Memory
AuthorList: Ulrich Drepper. November, 2007. Available: http://www.akkadia.org/drepper/cpumemory.pdf.
Description: A fantastic read about modern memory systems, starting at DRAM and going all the way up to virtualization and cache-optimized algorithms.

Title: An Introduction to Disk Drive Modeling
AuthorList: C. Ruemmler, J. Wilkes. IEEE Computer, 27:3, March 1994.
Description: A terriﬁc introduction to the basics of disk operation. Some pieces are out of date, but most of the basics remain.

Title: Analysis of Scanning Policies for Reducing Disk Seek Times
AuthorList: E.G. Coffman, L.A. Klimko, B. Ryan SIAM Journal of Computing, September 1972, Vol 1. No 3.
Description: Some of the early work in the ﬁeld of disk scheduling.

Title: Anticipatory Scheduling: A Disk-scheduling Framework To Overcome Deceptive Idleness In Synchronous I/O
AuthorList: Sitaram Iyer, Peter Druschel. SOSP ’01, October 2001.
Description: A cool paper showing how waiting can improve disk scheduling: better requests may be on their way!

Title: Barracuda ES.2 data sheet
AuthorList: Seagate, Inc.. Available at this website, at least, it was: http://www.seagate.com/docs/pdf/datasheet/disc/ds_barracuda_es.pdf.
Description: A data sheet; read at your own risk. Risk of what? Boredom.

Title: Cheetah 15K.5
AuthorList: Seagate, Inc.. Available at this website, we’re pretty sure it is: http://www.seagate.com/docs/pdf/datasheet/disc/ds-cheetah-15k-5-us.pdf.
Description: See above commentary on data sheets.

Title: Disk Scheduling Algorithms Based On Rotational Position
AuthorList: D. Jacobson, J. Wilkes. Technical Report HPL-CSP-91-7rev1, Hewlett-Packard, February 1991.
Description: A more modern take on disk scheduling. It remains a technical report (and not a published paper) because the authors were scooped by Seltzer et al. [S90].

Title: Disk Scheduling Revisited
AuthorList: Margo Seltzer, Peter Chen, John Ousterhout. USENIX 1990.
Description: A paper that talks about how rotation matters too in the world of disk scheduling.

Title: MEMS-based storage devices and standard disk interfaces: A square peg in a round hole?
AuthorList: Steven W. Schlosser, Gregory R. Ganger FAST ’04, pp. 87-100, 2004
Description: While the MEMS aspect of this paper hasn’t yet made an impact, the discussion of the contract between ﬁle systems and disks is wonderful and a lasting contribution. We later build on this work to study the Unwritten Contract of Solid State Drives” [HK+17]

Title: More Than an Interface: SCSI vs. ATA
AuthorList: Dave Anderson, Jim Dykes, Erik Riedel. FAST ’03, 2003.
Description: One of the best recent-ish references on how modern disk drives really work; a must read for anyone interested in knowing more.

Title: The Unwritten Contract of Solid State Drives
AuthorList: Jun He, Sudarsun Kannan, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. EuroSys ’17, Belgrade, Serbia, April 2017.
Description: We take the idea of the unwritten contract, and extend it to SSDs. Using SSDs well seems as complicated than hard drives, and sometimes more so.

Title: An Analysis of Data Corruption in the Storage Stack
AuthorList: Lakshmi N. Bairavasundaram, Garth R. Goodson, Bianca Schroeder, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. FAST ’08, San Jose, CA, February 2008.
Description: Our own work analyzing how often disks actually corrupt your data. Not often, but sometimes! And thus something a reliable storage system must consider.

Title: Byzantine Generals in Action: Implementing Fail-Stop Processors
AuthorList: F.B. Schneider. ACM Transactions on Computer Systems, 2(2):145154, May 1984.
Description: Finally, a paper that is not about RAID! This paper is actually about how systems fail, and how to make something behave in a fail-stop manner.

Title: Disk Shadowing
AuthorList: D. Bitton and J. Gray. VLDB 1988.
Description: One of the ﬁrst papers to discuss mirroring, therein called "shadowing”.

Title: Disk Striping
AuthorList: K. Salem, H. Garcia-Molina. IEEE International Conference on Data Engineering, 1986.
Description: And yes, another early RAID work. There are a lot of these, which kind of came out of the woodwork when the RAID paper was published in SIGMOD.

Title: File System Design for an NFS File Server Appliance
AuthorList: Dave Hitz, James Lau, Michael Malcolm. USENIX Winter 1994, San Francisco, California, 1994.
Description: The sparse paper introducing a landmark product in storage, the write-anywhere ﬁle layout or WAFL ﬁle system that underlies the NetApp ﬁle server.

Title: Journal-guided Resynchronization for Software RAID
AuthorList: Timothy E. Denehy, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST 2005.
Description: Our own work on the consistent-update problem. Here we solve it for Software RAID by integrating the journaling machinery of the ﬁle system above with the software RAID beneath it.

Title: Providing Fault Tolerance in Parallel Secondary Storage Systems
AuthorList: A. Park, K. Balasubramaniam. Department of Computer Science, Princeton, CS-TR-O57-86, November 1986.
Description: Another early work on RAID.

Title: Redundant Arrays of Inexpensive Disks
AuthorList: D. Patterson, G. Gibson, R. Katz. SIGMOD 1988. This is considered the RAID paper, written by famous authors Patterson, Gibson, and Katz.
Description: The paper has since won many test-of-time awards and ushered in the RAID era, including the name RAID itself!

Title: Row-Diagonal Parity for Double Disk Failure Correction
AuthorList: P. Corbett, B. English, A. Goel, T. Grcanac, S. Kleiman, J. Leong, S. Sankar. FAST ’04, February 2004.
Description: Though not the ﬁrst paper on a RAID system with two disks for parity, it is a recent and highly-understandable version of said idea. Read it to learn more.

Title: Small Disk Arrays – The Emerging Approach to High Performance
AuthorList: F. Kurzweil. Presentation at Spring COMPCON ’88, March 1, 1988, San Francisco, California.
Description: Another early RAID reference.

Title: Striping in a RAID level 5 disk array
AuthorList: Peter M. Chen and Edward K. Lee. SIGMETRICS 1995.
Description: A nice analysis of some of the important parameters in a RAID-5 disk array.

Title: Synchronized Disk Interleaving
AuthorList: M.Y. Kim. IEEE Transactions on Computers, Volume C-35: 11, November 1986.
Description: Some of the earliest work on RAID is found here.

Title: A Fast File System for UNIX
AuthorList: Marshall K. McKusick, William N. Joy, Sam J. Lefﬂer, Robert S. Fabry. ACM TOCS, 2:3, August 1984.
Description: We’ll talk about the Fast File System (FFS) explicitly later on. Here, we refer to it because of all the other random fun things it introduced, like long ﬁle names and symbolic links. Sometimes, when you are building a system to improve one thing, you improve a lot of other things along the way.

Title: Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment
AuthorList: W. Richard Stevens and Stephen A. Rago. Addison-Wesley, 2005.
Description: We have probably referenced this book a few hundred thousand times. It is that useful to you, if you care to become an awesome systems programmer.

Title: All File Systems Are Not Created Equal: On the Complexity of Crafting Crash-Consistent Applications
AuthorList: Thanumalayan S. Pillai, Vijay Chidambaram, Ramnatthan Alagappan, Samer Al-Kiswany, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, and Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. OSDI ’14, Broomﬁeld, Colorado, October 2014.
Description: The full conference paper on this topic – with many more details and interesting tidbits than the ﬁrst workshop paper above.

Title: Capability-Based Computer Systems
AuthorList: Henry M. Levy. Digital Press, 1984. Available: http://homes.cs.washington.edu/~levy/capabook.
Description: An excellent overview of early capability-based systems.

Title: Checking for Race Conditions in File Accesses
AuthorList: Matt Bishop, Michael Dilger. Computing Systems 9:2, 1996.
Description: A great description of the TOCTTOU problem and its presence in ﬁle systems.

Title: Portably Solving File TOCTTOU Races with Hardness Ampliﬁcation
AuthorList: D. Tsafrir, T. Hertz, D. Wagner, D. Da Silva. FAST ’08, San Jose, California, 2008.
Description: Not the paper that introduced TOCTTOU, but a recent-ish and well-done description of the problem and a way to solve the problem in a portable manner.

Title: Principles of Computer System Design
AuthorList: Jerome H. Saltzer and M. Frans Kaashoek. Morgan-Kaufmann, 2009.
Description: This tour de force of systems is a must-read for anybody interested in the ﬁeld. It’s how they teach systems at MIT. Read it once, and then read it a few more times to let it all soak in.

Title: Processes as Files
AuthorList: Tom J. Killian. USENIX, June 1984.
Description: The paper that introduced the /proc ﬁle system, where each process can be treated as a ﬁle within a pseudo ﬁle system. A clever idea that you can still see in modern U NIX systems.

Title: The xv6 Operating System
AuthorList: Russ Cox, Frans Kaashoek, Robert Morris, Nickolai Zeldovich. From: https://github.com/mit-pdos/xv6-public.
Description: As mentioned before, a cool and simple Unix implementation. We have been using an older version (2012-01-30-1-g1c41342) and hence some examples in the book may not match the latest in the source.

Title: Towards Efﬁcient, Portable Application-Level Consistency
AuthorList: Thanumalayan S. Pillai, Vijay Chidambaram, Joo-Young Hwang, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, and Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. HotDep ’13, November 2013.
Description: Our own work that shows how readily applications can make mistakes in committing data to disk; in particular, assumptions about the ﬁle system creep into applications and thus make the applications work correctly only if they are running on a speciﬁc ﬁle system.

Title: TxFS: Leveraging File-System Crash Consistency to Provide ACID Transactions
AuthorList: Y. Hu, Z. Zhu, I. Neal, Y. Kwon, T. Cheng, V. Chidambaram, E. Witchel. USENIX ATC ’18, June 2018.
Description: The best paper at USENIX ATC ’18, and a good recent place to start to learn about transactional ﬁle systems.

Title: A Five-Year Study of File-System Metadata
AuthorList: Nitin Agrawal, William J. Bolosky, John R. Douceur, Jacob R. Lorch. FAST ’07, San Jose, California, February 2007.
Description: An excellent recent analysis of how ﬁle systems are actually used. Use the bibliography within to follow the trail of ﬁle-system analysis papers back to the early 1980s.

Title: Inside the Windows NT File System
AuthorList: Helen Custer. Microsoft Press, 1994.
Description: A short book about NTFS; there are probably ones with more technical details elsewhere.

Title: Scalability in the XFS File System
AuthorList: Adan Sweeney, Doug Doucette, Wei Hu, Curtis Anderson, Mike Nishimoto, Geoff Peck. USENIX ’96, January 1996, San Diego, California.
Description: The ﬁrst attempt to make scalability of operations, including things like having millions of ﬁles in a directory, a central focus. A great example of pushing an idea to the extreme. The key idea behind this ﬁle system: everything is a tree. We should have a chapter on this ﬁle system too.

Title: Scale and Performance in a Distributed File System
AuthorList: John H. Howard, Michael L. Kazar, Sherri G. Menees, David A. Nichols, M. Satyanarayanan, Robert N. Sidebotham, Michael J. West.. ACM TOCS, Volume 6:1, February 1988.
Description: A classic distributed ﬁle system; we’ll be learning more about it later, don’t worry.

Title: The FAT File System
AuthorList: Andries Brouwer. September, 2002. Available online at: http://www.win.tue.nl/~aeb/linux/fs/fat/fat.html.
Description: A nice clean description of FAT. The ﬁle system kind, not the bacon kind. Though you have to admit, bacon fat probably tastes better.

Title: The Second Extended File System: Internal Layout
AuthorList: Dave Poirier. 2009. Available: http://www.nongnu.org/ext2-doc/ext2.html.
Description: Some details on ext2, a very simple Linux ﬁle system based on FFS, the Berkeley Fast File System. We’ll be reading about it in the next chapter.

Title: The U NIX Time-Sharing System
AuthorList: M. Ritchie, K. Thompson. CACM Volume 17:7, 1974.
Description: The original paper about UNIX. Read it to see the underpinnings of much of modern operating systems.

Title: UBC: An Efﬁcient Uniﬁed I/O and Memory Caching Subsystem for NetBSD
AuthorList: Chuck Silvers. FREENIX, 2000.
Description: A nice paper about NetBSD’s integration of ﬁle-system buffer caching and the virtual-memory page cache. Many other systems do the same type of thing.

Title: ZFS: The Last Word in File Systems
AuthorList: Jeff Bonwick and Bill Moore. Available from: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/zfs_last.pdf.
Description: One of the most recent important ﬁle systems, full of features and awesomeness. We should have a chapter on it, and perhaps soon will.

Title: A Fast File System for UNIX
AuthorList: Marshall K. McKusick, William N. Joy, Sam J. Lefﬂer, Robert S. Fabry. ACM TOCS, 2:3, August 1984. McKusick was recently honored with the IEEE Reynold B.
Description: Johnson award for his contributions to ﬁle systems, much of which was based on his work building FFS. In his acceptance speech, he discussed the original FFS software: only 1200 lines of code! Modern versions are a little more complex, e.g., the BSD FFS descendant now is in the 50-thousand lines-of-code range.

Title: Hardware Technology Trends and Database Opportunities
AuthorList: David A. Patterson. Keynote Lecture at SIGMOD ’98, June 1998.
Description: A great and simple overview of disk technology trends and how they change over time.

Title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces” (Chapter: Hard Disk Drives)
AuthorList: Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau and Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau . Arpaci-Dusseau Books, 2014.
Description: There is no way you should be reading about FFS without having ﬁrst understood hard drives in some detail. If you try to do so, please instead go directly to jail; do not pass go, and, critically, do not collect 200 much-needed simoleons.

Title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces” (Chapter: File System Implementation)
AuthorList: Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau and Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau. Arpaci-Dusseau Books, 2014.
Description: As above, it makes little sense to read this chapter unless you have read (and understood) the chapter on ﬁle system implementation. Otherwise, we’ll be throwing around terms like "inode" and "indirect block” and you’ll be like "huh?” and that is no fun for either of us.

Title: The Design of the SEER Predictive Caching System
AuthorList: G. H. Kuenning. MOBICOMM ’94, Santa Cruz, California, December 1994.
Description: According to Kuenning, this is the best overview of the SEER project, which led to (among other things) the collection of these traces.

Title: A Fast File System for UNIX
AuthorList: Marshall K. McKusick, William N. Joy, Sam J. Lefﬂer, Robert S. Fabry. ACM Transactions on Computing Systems, Volume 2:3, August 1984.
Description: You already know enough about FFS, right? But come on, it is OK to re-reference important papers.

Title: All File Systems Are Not Created Equal: On the Complexity of Crafting Crash-Consistent Applications
AuthorList: Thanumalayan Sankaranarayana Pillai, Vijay Chidambaram, Ramnatthan Alagappan, Samer Al-Kiswany, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. OSDI ’14, Broomﬁeld, Colorado, October 2014.
Description: A paper in which we study what ﬁle systems guarantee after crashes, and show that applications expect something different, leading to all sorts of interesting problems.

Title: Analysis and Evolution of Journaling File Systems
AuthorList: Vijayan Prabhakaran, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. USENIX ’05, Anaheim, California, April 2005.
Description: An early paper we wrote analyzing how journaling ﬁle systems work.

Title: Coerced Cache Eviction and Discreet-Mode Journaling
AuthorList: Abhishek Rajimwale, Vijay Chidambaram, Deepak Ramamurthi, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. DSN ’11, Hong Kong, China, June 2011.
Description: Our own paper on the problem of disks that buffer writes in a memory cache instead of forcing them to disk, even when explicitly told not to do that! Our solution to overcome this problem: if you want A to be written to disk before B, ﬁrst write A, then send a lot of "dummy” writes to disk, hopefully causing A to be forced to disk to make room for them in the cache. A neat if impractical solution.

Title: Consistency Without Ordering
AuthorList: Vijay Chidambaram, Tushar Sharma, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST ’12, San Jose, California.
Description: A recent paper of ours about a new form of crash consistency based on back pointers. Read it for the exciting details!

Title: EXT3, Journaling Filesystem
AuthorList: Stephen Tweedie.
Description: Talk at the Ottawa Linux Symposium, July 2000. olstrans.sourceforge.net/release/OLS2000-ext3/OLS2000-ext3.html A transcript of a talk given by Tweedie on ext3.

Title: ffsck: The Fast File System Checker
AuthorList: Ao Ma, Chris Dragga, Andrea C. ArpaciDusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST ’13, San Jose, California, February 2013.
Description: A recent paper of ours detailing how to make fsck an order of magnitude faster. Some of the ideas have already been incorporated into the BSD ﬁle system checker [MK96] and are deployed today.

Title: Fsck – The U NIX File System Check Program
AuthorList: Marshall Kirk McKusick and T. J. Kowalski. Revised in 1996.
Description: Describes the ﬁrst comprehensive ﬁle-system checking tool, the eponymous fsck. Written by some of the same people who brought you FFS.

Title: IRON File Systems
AuthorList: Vijayan Prabhakaran, Lakshmi N. Bairavasundaram, Nitin Agrawal, Haryadi S. Gunawi, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. SOSP ’05, Brighton, England, October 2005.
Description: A paper mostly focused on studying how ﬁle systems react to disk failures. Towards the end, we introduce a transaction checksum to speed up logging, which was eventually adopted into Linux ext4.

Title: Journaling the Linux ext2fs File System
AuthorList: Stephen C. Tweedie. The Fourth Annual Linux Expo, May 1998.
Description: Tweedie did much of the heavy lifting in adding journaling to the Linux ext2 ﬁle system; the result, not surprisingly, is called ext3. Some nice design decisions include the strong focus on backwards compatibility, e.g., you can just add a journaling ﬁle to an existing ext2 ﬁle system and then mount it as an ext3 ﬁle system.

Title: Metadata Update Performance in File Systems
AuthorList: Gregory R. Ganger and Yale N. Patt. OSDI ’94.
Description: A clever paper about using careful ordering of writes as the main way to achieve consistency. Implemented later in BSD-based systems.

Title: Optimistic Crash Consistency
AuthorList: Vijay Chidambaram, Thanu S. Pillai, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau . SOSP ’13, Nemacolin Woodlands Resort, PA, November 2013.
Description: Our work on a more optimistic and higher performance journaling protocol. For workloads that call fsync() a lot, performance can be greatly improved.

Title: Reimplementing the Cedar File System Using Logging and Group Commit
AuthorList: Robert Hagmann. SOSP ’87, Austin, Texas, November 1987.
Description: The ﬁrst work (that we know of) that applied write-ahead logging (a.k.a. journaling) to a ﬁle system.

Title: SQCK: A Declarative File System Checker
AuthorList: Haryadi S. Gunawi, Abhishek Rajimwale, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. OSDI ’08, San Diego, California.
Description: Our own paper on a new and better way to build a ﬁle system checker using SQL queries. We also show some problems with the existing checker, ﬁnding numerous bugs and odd behaviors, a direct result of the complexity of fsck.

Title: The Linux ext2 File System
AuthorList: Theodore Ts’o, June, 2001.. Available online here: http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/ext2.html.
Description: A simple Linux ﬁle system based on the ideas found in FFS. For a while it was quite heavily used; now it is really just in the kernel as an example of a simple ﬁle system.

Title: ZFS: The Last Word in File Systems
AuthorList: Jeff Bonwick and Bill Moore. Available online: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/zfs_last.pdf.
Description: ZFS uses copy-on-write and journaling, actually, as in some cases, logging writes to disk will perform better.

Title: A Better Update Policy
AuthorList: Jeffrey C. Mogul. USENIX ATC ’94, June 1994.
Description: In this paper, Mogul ﬁnds that read workloads can be harmed by buffering writes for too long and then sending them to the disk in a big burst. Thus, he recommends sending writes more frequently and in smaller batches.

Title: A Fast File System for UNIX
AuthorList: Marshall K. McKusick, William N. Joy, Sam J. Lefﬂer, Robert S. Fabry. ACM TOCS, Volume 2:3, August 1984.
Description: The original FFS paper; see the chapter on FFS for more details.

Title: BTRFS: The Linux B-Tree Filesystem
AuthorList: Ohad Rodeh, Josef Bacik, Chris Mason. ACM Transactions on Storage, Volume 9 Issue 3, August 2013.
Description: Finally, a good paper on BTRFS, a modern take on copy-on-write ﬁle systems.

Title: De-indirection for Flash-based SSDs with Nameless Writes
AuthorList: Yiying Zhang, Leo Prasath Arulraj, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST ’13, San Jose, California, February 2013.
Description: Our paper on a new way to build ﬂash-based storage devices, to avoid redundant mappings in the ﬁle system and FTL. The idea is for the device to pick the physical location of a write, and return the address to the ﬁle system, which stores the mapping.

Title: Design and Implementation of the Log-structured File System
AuthorList: Mendel Rosenblum and John Ousterhout. SOSP ’91, Paciﬁc Grove, CA, October 1991.
Description: The original SOSP paper about LFS, which has been cited by hundreds of other papers and inspired many real systems.

Title: Design and Implementation of the Log-structured File System
AuthorList: Mendel Rosenblum. http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Pubs/TechRpts/1992/CSD-92-696.pdf.
Description: The award-winning dissertation about LFS, with many of the details missing from the paper.

Title: File System Design for an NFS File Server Appliance
AuthorList: Dave Hitz, James Lau, Michael Malcolm. USENIX Spring ’94.
Description: WAFL takes many ideas from LFS and RAID and puts it into a high-speed NFS appliance for the multi-billion dollar storage company NetApp.

Title: File system logging versus clustering: a performance comparison
AuthorList: Margo Seltzer, Keith A. Smith, Hari Balakrishnan, Jacqueline Chang, Sara McMains, Venkata Padmanabhan. USENIX 1995 Technical Conference, New Orleans, Louisiana, 1995.
Description: A paper that showed the LFS performance sometimes has problems, particularly for workloads with many calls to fsync() (such as database workloads). The paper was controversial at the time.

Title: Hardware Technology Trends and Database Opportunities
AuthorList: David A. Patterson. ACM SIGMOD ’98 Keynote, 1998. Available online here: http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/ ~pattrsn/talks/keynote.html.
Description: A great set of slides on technology trends in computer systems. Hopefully, Patterson will create another of these sometime soon.

Title: Improving the Performance of Log-structured File Systems with Adaptive Methods
AuthorList: Jeanna Neefe Matthews, Drew Roselli, Adam M. Costello, Randolph Y. Wang, Thomas E. Anderson. SOSP 1997, pages 238-251, October, Saint Malo, France.
Description: A more recent paper detailing better policies for cleaning in LFS.

Title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces (Chapter: Flash-based Solid State Drives)
AuthorList: Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau and Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau. Arpaci-Dusseau Books, 2014.
Description: A bit gauche to refer you to another chapter in this very book, but who are we to judge?

Title: Physical Integrity in a Large Segmented Database
AuthorList: R. Lorie. ACM Transactions on Databases, Volume 2:1, 1977.
Description: The original idea of shadow paging is presented here.

Title: The Unwritten Contract of of Solid State Drives
AuthorList: Jun He, Sudarsun Kannan, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. EuroSys ’17, April 2017.
Description: Which unwritten rules one must follow to extract high performance from an SSD? Interestingly, both request scale (large or parallel requests) and locality still matter, even on SSDs. The more things change ...

Title: Write-Only Disk Caches
AuthorList: Jon A. Solworth, Cyril U. Orji. SIGMOD ’90, Atlantic City, New Jersey, May 1990.
Description: An early study of write buffering and its beneﬁts. However, buffering for too long can be harmful: see Mogul [M94] for details.

Title: ZFS: The Last Word in File Systems
AuthorList: Jeff Bonwick and Bill Moore. Copy Available: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/zfs_last.pdf.
Description: Slides on ZFS; unfortunately, there is no great ZFS paper (yet). Maybe you will write one, so we can cite it here?

Title: A Log Buffer-Based Flash Translation Layer by Using Fully-Associative Sector Translation.
AuthorList: Sang-won Lee, Tae-Sun Chung, Dong-Ho Lee, Sangwon Park, Ha-Joo Song. ACM Transactions on Embedded Computing Systems, Volume 6, Number 3, July 2007
Description: A terriﬁc paper about how to build hybrid log/block mappings.

Title: A Space-Efﬁcient Flash Translation Layer For Compact Flash Systems
AuthorList: Jesung Kim, Jong Min Kim, Sam H. Noh, Sang Lyul Min, Yookun Cho. IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics, Volume 48, Number 2, May 2002.
Description: One of the earliest proposals to suggest hybrid mappings.

Title: A Survey of Address Translation Technologies for Flash Memories
AuthorList: Dongzhe Ma, Jianhua Feng, Guoliang Li. ACM Computing Surveys, Volume 46, Number 3, January 2014.
Description: Probably the best recent survey of ﬂash and related technologies.

Title: Amazon Pricing Study
AuthorList: Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau. February, 2015.
Description: This is not an actual paper, but rather one of the authors going to Amazon and looking at current prices of hard drives and SSDs. You too can repeat this study, and see what the costs are today. Do it!

Title: An Aggressive Worn-out Flash Block Management Scheme To Alleviate SSD Performance Degradation
AuthorList: Ping Huang, Guanying Wu, Xubin He, Weijun Xiao. EuroSys ’14, 2014.
Description: Recent work showing how to really get the most out of worn-out ﬂash blocks; neat!

Title: Characterizing Flash Memory: Anomalies, Observations, and Applications
AuthorList: L. M. Grupp, A. M. Caulﬁeld, J. Coburn, S. Swanson, E. Yaakobi, P. H. Siegel, J. K. Wolf. IEEE MICRO ’09, New York, New York, December 2009.
Description: Another excellent characterization of ﬂash performance.

Title: CORFU: A Shared Log Design for Flash Clusters
AuthorList: M. Balakrishnan, D. Malkhi, V. Prabhakaran, T. Wobber, M. Wei, J. D. Davis. NSDI ’12, San Jose, California, April 2012.
Description: A new way to think about designing a high-performance replicated log for clusters using Flash.

Title: De-indirection for Flash-based SSDs with Nameless Writes
AuthorList: Yiying Zhang, Leo Prasath Arulraj, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST ’13, San Jose, California, February 2013.
Description: Our research on a new idea to reduce mapping table space; the key is to re-use the pointers in the ﬁle system above to store locations of blocks, instead of adding another level of indirection.

Title: Design Tradeoffs for SSD Performance
AuthorList: N. Agrawal, V. Prabhakaran, T. Wobber, J. D. Davis, M. Manasse, R. Panigrahy. USENIX ’08, San Diego California, June 2008.
Description: An excellent overview of what goes into SSD design.

Title: DFTL: a Flash Translation Layer Employing Demand-Based Selective Caching of Page-Level Address Mappings
AuthorList: Aayush Gupta, Youngjae Kim, Bhuvan Urgaonkar. ASPLOS ’09, Washington, D.C., March 2009.
Description: This paper gives an excellent overview of different strategies for cleaning within hybrid SSDs as well as a new scheme which saves mapping table space and improves performance under many workloads.

Title: Failure Mechanisms and Models for Semiconductor Devices
AuthorList: Unknown author. Report JEP122F, November 2010. Available on the internet at this exciting so-called web site: http://www.jedec.org/sites/default/files/docs/JEP122F.pdf.
Description: A highly detailed discussion of what is going on at the device level and how such devices fail. Only for those not faint of heart. Or physicists. Or both.

Title: Gordon: Using Flash Memory to Build Fast, Power-efﬁcient Clusters for Data-intensive Applications
AuthorList: Adrian M. Caulﬁeld, Laura M. Grupp, Steven Swanson. ASPLOS ’09, Washington, D.C., March 2009.
Description: Early research on assembling ﬂash into larger-scale clusters; deﬁnitely worth a read.

Title: List of Ships Sunk by Icebergs
AuthorList: Many authors. Available at this location on the "web": http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List of ships sunk by icebergs.
Description: Yes, there is a wikipedia page about ships sunk by icebergs. It is a really boring page and basically everyone knows the only ship the iceberg-sinking-maﬁa cares about is the Titanic.

Title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces
AuthorList: Chapters: Crash Consistency: FSCK and Journaling and Log-Structured File Systems. Remzi Arpaci-Dusseau and Andrea Arpaci-Dusseau.
Description: A lot more detail here about how logging can be used in ﬁle systems; some of the same ideas can be applied inside devices too as need be.

Title: Performance Charts Hard Drives
AuthorList: Tom’s Hardware. January 2015. Available here: http://www.tomshardware.com/charts/enterprise-hdd-charts.
Description: Yet another site with performance data, this time focusing on hard drives.

Title: The Seagate 600 and 600 Pro SSD Review
AuthorList: Anand Lal Shimpi. AnandTech, May 7, 2013. Available: http://www.anandtech.com/show/6935/seagate-600-ssd-review.
Description: One of many SSD performance measurements available on the internet. Haven’t heard of the internet? No problem. Just go to your web browser and type "internet" into the search tool. You’ll be amazed at what you can learn.

Title: The SSD Endurance Experiment
AuthorList: Geoff Gasior. The Tech Report, September 19, 2014. Available: http://techreport.com/review/27062.
Description: A nice set of simple experiments measuring performance of SSDs over time. There are many other similar studies; use google to ﬁnd more.

Title: The Unwritten Contract of Solid State Drives
AuthorList: Jun He, Sudarsun Kannan, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. EuroSys ’17, Belgrade, Serbia, April 2017.
Description: Our own paper which lays out ﬁve rules clients should follow in order to get the best performance out of modern SSDs. The rules are request scale, locality, aligned sequentiality, grouping by death time, and uniform lifetime. Read the paper for details!

Title: Understanding Intrinsic Characteristics and System Implications of Flash Memory based Solid State Drives
AuthorList: Feng Chen, David A. Koufaty, and Xiaodong Zhang. SIGMETRICS/Performance ’09, Seattle, Washington, June 2009.
Description: An excellent overview of SSD performance problems circa 2009 (though now a little dated).

Title: Understanding TLC Flash
AuthorList: Kristian Vatto. AnandTech, September, 2012. Available: http://www.anandtech.com/show/5067/understanding-tlc-nand.
Description: A short description about TLC ﬂash and its characteristics.

Title: Write Endurance in Flash Drives: Measurements and Analysis
AuthorList: Simona Boboila, Peter Desnoyers. FAST ’10, San Jose, California, February 2010.
Description: A cool paper that reverse engineers ﬂash-device lifetimes. Endurance sometimes far exceeds manufacturer predictions, by up to 100×.

Title: ZFS: The Last Word in File Systems
AuthorList: Jeff Bonwick and Bill Moore. Available here: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/zfs_last.pdf.
Description: Was this the last word in ﬁle systems? No, but maybe it’s close.

Title: An Analysis of Data Corruption in the Storage Stack
AuthorList: Lakshmi N. Bairavasundaram, Garth R. Goodson, Bianca Schroeder, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. FAST ’08, San Jose, CA, February 2008.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to truly study disk corruption in great detail, focusing on how often such corruption occurs over three years for over 1.5 million drives.

Title: An Analysis of Latent Sector Errors in Disk Drives
AuthorList: L. Bairavasundaram, G. Goodson, S. Pasupathy, J. Schindler. SIGMETRICS ’07, San Diego, CA.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to study latent sector errors in detail. The paper also won the Kenneth C. Sevcik Outstanding Student Paper award, named after a brilliant researcher and wonderful guy who passed away too soon. To show the OSTEP authors it was possible to move from the U.S. to Canada, Ken once sang us the Canadian national anthem, standing up in the middle of a restaurant to do so. We chose the U.S., but got this memory.

Title: An Arithmetic Checksum for Serial Transmissions
AuthorList: John G. Fletcher. IEEE Transactions on Communication, Vol. 30:1, January 1982.
Description: Fletcher’s original work on his eponymous checksum. He didn’t call it the Fletcher checksum, rather he just didn’t call it anything; later, others named it after him. So don’t blame old Fletch for this seeming act of braggadocio. This anecdote might remind you of Rubik; Rubik never called it "Rubik’s cube”; rather, he just called it "my cube.”

Title: Checksums and Error Control
AuthorList: Peter M. Fenwick. Copy available online here: http://www.ostep.org/Citations/checksums-03.pdf.
Description: A great simple tutorial on checksums, available to you for the amazing cost of free.

Title: Commercial Fault Tolerance: A Tale of Two Systems
AuthorList: Wendy Bartlett, Lisa Spainhower. IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, Vol. 1:1, January 2004.
Description: This classic in building fault tolerant systems is an excellent overview of the state of the art from both IBM and Tandem. Another must read for those interested in the area.

Title: Cyclic Redundancy Checks
AuthorList: unknown. Available: http://www.mathpages.com/ home/kmath458.htm.
Description: A super clear and concise description of CRCs. The internet is full of information, as it turns out.

Title: Design and Implementation of the Log-structured File System
AuthorList: Mendel Rosenblum and John Ousterhout. SOSP ’91, Paciﬁc Grove, CA, October 1991.
Description: So cool we cite it again.

Title: File System Design for an NFS File Server Appliance
AuthorList: Dave Hitz, James Lau, Michael Malcolm. USENIX Spring ’94.
Description: The pioneering paper that describes the ideas and product at the heart of NetApp’s core. Based on this system, NetApp has grown into a multi-billion dollar storage company. To learn more about NetApp, read Hitz’s autobiography "How to Castrate a Bull” (which is the actual title, no joking). And you thought you could avoid bull castration by going into CS.

Title: Implementing Fault-Tolerant Services Using The State Machine Approach: A Tutorial
AuthorList: Fred B. Schneider. ACM Surveys, Vol. 22, No. 4, December 1990.
Description: How to build fault tolerant services. A must read for those building distributed systems.

Title: IRON File Systems
AuthorList: V. Prabhakaran, L. Bairavasundaram, N. Agrawal, H. Gunawi, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau. SOSP ’05, Brighton, England.
Description: Our paper on how disks have partial failure modes, and a detailed study of how modern ﬁle systems react to such failures. As it turns out, rather poorly! We found numerous bugs, design ﬂaws, and other oddities in this work. Some of this has fed back into the Linux community, thus improving ﬁle system reliability. You’re welcome!

Title: Parity Lost and Parity Regained
AuthorList: Andrew Krioukov, Lakshmi N. Bairavasundaram, Garth R. Goodson, Kiran Srinivasan, Randy Thelen, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST ’08, San Jose, CA, February 2008.
Description: This work explores how different checksum schemes work (or don’t work) in protecting data. We reveal a number of interesting ﬂaws in current protection strategies.

Title: Row-Diagonal Parity for Double Disk Failure Correction
AuthorList: P. Corbett, B. English, A. Goel, T. Grcanac, S. Kleiman, J. Leong, S. Sankar. FAST ’04, San Jose, CA, February 2004.
Description: An early paper on how extra redundancy helps to solve the combined full-disk-failure/partial-disk-failure problem. Also a nice example of how to mix more theoretical work with practical.

Title: Zettabyte Reliability with Flexible End-to-end Data Integrity
AuthorList: Y. Zhang, D. Myers, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau. MSST ’13, Long Beach, California, May 2013.
Description: How to add data protection to the page cache of a system. Out of space, otherwise we would write something...

Title: Congestion Avoidance and Control
AuthorList: Van Jacobson. SIGCOMM ’88 .
Description: A pioneering paper on how clients should adjust to perceived network congestion; deﬁnitely one of the key pieces of technology underlying the Internet, and a must read for anyone serious about systems, and for Van Jacobson’s relatives because well relatives should read all of your papers.

Title: End-To-End Arguments in System Design
AuthorList: Jerome H. Saltzer, David P. Reed, David D. Clark. ACM TOCS, 2:4, November 1984.
Description: A beautiful discussion of layering, abstraction, and where functionality must ultimately reside in computer systems.

Title: Implementing Remote Procedure Calls
AuthorList: Andrew D. Birrell, Bruce Jay Nelson. ACM TOCS, Volume 2:1, February 1984.
Description: The foundational RPC system upon which all others build. Yes, another pioneering effort from our friends at Xerox PARC.

Title: Memory Coherence in Shared Virtual Memory Systems
AuthorList: Kai Li and Paul Hudak. ACM TOCS, 7:4, November 1989.
Description: The introduction of software-based shared memory via virtual memory. An intriguing idea for sure, but not a lasting or good one in the end.

Title: Principles of Computer System Design
AuthorList: Jerome H. Saltzer and M. Frans Kaashoek. Morgan-Kaufmann, 2009.
Description: An excellent book on systems, and a must for every bookshelf. One of the few terriﬁc discussions on naming we’ve seen.

Title: The ALOHA System — Another Alternative for Computer Communications
AuthorList: Norman Abramson. The 1970 Fall Joint Computer Conference.
Description: The ALOHA network pioneered some basic concepts in networking, including exponential back-off and retransmit, which formed the basis for communication in shared-bus Ethernet networks for years.

Title: The Effectiveness of Checksums for Embedded Control Networks
AuthorList: Theresa C. Maxino and Philip J. Koopman. IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, 6:1, January ’09.
Description: A nice overview of basic checksum machinery and some performance and robustness comparisons between them.

Title: File System Design for an NFS File Server Appliance
AuthorList: Dave Hitz, James Lau, Michael Malcolm. USENIX Winter 1994. San Francisco, California, 1994.
Description: Hitz et al. were greatly inﬂuenced by previous work on log-structured ﬁle systems.

Title: Kerberos: An Authentication Service for Computer Networks
AuthorList: B. Clifford Neuman, Theodore Ts’o. IEEE Communications, 32(9):33-38, September 1994.
Description: Kerberos is an early and hugely inﬂuential authentication service. We probably should write a book chapter about it sometime...

Title: La Begueule
AuthorList: Francois-Marie Arouet a.k.a. Voltaire. Published in 1772.
Description: Voltaire said a number of clever things, this being but one example. For example, Voltaire also said "If you have two religions in your land, the two will cut each others throats; but if you have thirty religions, they will dwell in peace.” What do you say to that, Democrats and Republicans?

Title: New NFS Tracing Tools and Techniques for System Analysis
AuthorList: Daniel Ellard and Margo Seltzer. LISA ’03, San Diego, California.
Description: An intricate, careful analysis of NFS done via passive tracing. By simply monitoring network trafﬁc, the authors show how to derive a vast amount of ﬁle system understanding.

Title: NFS Illustrated
AuthorList: Brent Callaghan. Addison-Wesley Professional Computing Series, 2000.
Description: A great NFS reference; incredibly thorough and detailed per the protocol itself.

Title: NFS Version 3: Design and Implementation
AuthorList: Brian Pawlowski, Chet Juszczak, Peter Staubach, Carl Smith, Diane Lebel, Dave Hitz. USENIX Summer 1994, pages 137-152.
Description: The small modiﬁcations that underlie NFS version 3.

Title: NFS: Network File System Protocol Speciﬁcation
AuthorList: Sun Microsystems, Inc. Request for Comments: 1094, March 1989. Available: http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1094.txt.
Description: The dreaded speciﬁcation; read it if you must, i.e., you are getting paid to read it. Hopefully, paid a lot. Cash money!

Title: The AWK Programming Language
AuthorList: Alfred V. Aho, Brian W. Kernighan, Peter J. Weinberger. Pearson, 1988 (1st edition).
Description: A concise, wonderful book about awk. We once had the pleasure of meeting Peter Weinberger; when he introduced himself, he said I’m Peter Weinberger, you know, the ’W’ in awk?” As huge awk fans, this was a moment to savor. One of us (Remzi) then said, I love awk! I particularly love the book, which makes everything so wonderfully clear.” Weinberger replied (crestfallen), "Oh, Kernighan wrote the book.”

Title: The Design and Implementation of the Log-structured File System
AuthorList: Mendel Rosenblum, John Ousterhout. Symposium on Operating Systems Principles (SOSP), 1991. LFS again.
Description: No, you can never get enough LFS.

Title: The NFS version 4 protocol
AuthorList: Brian Pawlowski, David Noveck, David Robinson, Robert Thurlow. 2nd International System Administration and Networking Conference (SANE 2000).
Description: Undoubtedly the most literary paper on NFS ever written.

Title: The Role of Distributed State
AuthorList: John K. Ousterhout. 1991. Available at this site: ftp://ftp.cs.berkeley.edu/ucb/sprite/papers/state.ps.
Description: A rarely referenced discussion of distributed state; a broader perspective on the problems and challenges.

Title: The Sun Network File System: Design, Implementation and Experience
AuthorList: Russel Sandberg. USENIX Summer 1986.
Description: The original NFS paper; though a bit of a challenging read, it is worthwhile to see the source of these wonderful ideas.

Title: Vnodes: An Architecture for Multiple File System Types in Sun U NIX
AuthorList: Steve R. Kleiman. USENIX Summer ’86, Atlanta, Georgia.
Description: This paper shows how to build a ﬂexible ﬁle system architecture into an operating system, enabling multiple different ﬁle system implementations to coexist. Now used in virtually every modern operating system in some form.

Title: A Comparison of File System Workloads
AuthorList: Drew Roselli, Jacob R. Lorch, Thomas E. Anderson. USENIX ’00, San Diego, California, June 2000.
Description: A more recent set of traces as compared to the Baker paper [B+91], with some interesting twists.

Title: A File is Not a File: Understanding the I/O Behavior of Apple Desktop Applications
AuthorList: Tyler Harter, Chris Dragga, Michael Vaughn, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. SOSP ’11, New York, New York, October 2011.
Description: Our own paper studying the behavior of Apple Desktop workloads; turns out they are a bit different than many of the server-based workloads the systems research community usually focuses upon. Also a good recent reference which points to a lot of related work.

Title: File system usage in Windows NT 4.0
AuthorList: Werner Vogels. SOSP ’99, Kiawah Island Resort, South Carolina, December 1999.
Description: A cool study of Windows workloads, which are inherently different than many of the U NIX-based studies that had previously been done.

Title: Measurements of a Distributed File System
AuthorList: Mary Baker, John Hartman, Martin Kupfer, Ken Shirriff, John Ousterhout. SOSP ’91, Paciﬁc Grove, California, October 1991.
Description: An early paper measuring how people use distributed ﬁle systems. Matches much of the intuition found in AFS.

Title: Scale and Performance in a Distributed File System
AuthorList: John H. Howard, Michael L. Kazar, Sherri G. Menees, David A. Nichols, M. Satyanarayanan, Robert N. Sidebotham, Michael J. West. ACM Transactions on Computing Systems (ACM TOCS), Volume 6:1, February 1988.
Description: The long journal version of the famous AFS system, still in use in a number of places throughout the world, and also probably the earliest clear thinking on how to build distributed ﬁle systems. A wonderful combination of the science of measurement and principled engineering.

Title: The ITC Distributed File System: Principles and Design
AuthorList: M. Satyanarayanan, J.H. Howard, D.A. Nichols, R.N. Sidebotham, A. Spector, M.J. West. SOSP ’85, Orcas Island, Washington, December 1985.
Description: The older paper about a distributed ﬁle system. Much of the basic design of AFS is in place in this older system, but not the improvements for scale. The name change to "Andrew” is an homage to two people both named Andrew, Andrew Carnegie and Andrew Mellon. These two rich dudes started the Carnegie Institute of Technology and the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, respectively, which eventually merged to become what is now known as Carnegie Mellon University.
